body: Sync Now Click Pull all HubSpot Contacts to Apollo Contacts to initiate a manual sync for Contacts. Pull all HubSpot Contacts to Apollo Contacts Contacts Click Pull Now to confirm your request. Pull Now Click Pull all HubSpot Companies to Apollo Accounts to initiate a manual sync for Companies. Pull all HubSpot Companies to Apollo Accounts Companies

title: Configure HubSpot "Basics" Settings
body: Configure Your Push Settings Launch Apollo and click Settings. Settings Click Integrations. Integrations Click View in the HubSpot section. View HubSpot From the "Basics" tab, you can access several configuration options for your Push Settings. In the Contacts section, enable the toggle to push any newly created Apollo Contacts to HubSpot. Push Settings Contacts Contacts If you only want to push Contacts that are in specific stages, click the first check-box and then use the drop-down to select the stages.

title: Configure HubSpot "Basics" Settings
body:
Contacts The Emails section allows you to configure how Apollo pushes outgoing and incoming emails to HubSpot. You can configure the following options: Emails Outgoing emails sent within Apollo: Pushes any outgoing emails that you send through Apollo to HubSpot

Outgoing emails not sent within Apollo: Pushes any outgoing emails that you send outside of Apollo through a mailbox connected to the platform to HubSpot

Incoming emails that are replies to emails sent within Apollo: Pushes replies to emails that

title: Configure HubSpot "Basics" Settings
body:
you send through Apollo to HubSpot

Incoming emails from all other sources: Pushes any replies to emails that you send outside of Apollo through a mailbox connected to the platform to HubSpot

Push emails even if sender or recipient doesn't exist in HubSpot: Pushes emails from any of the enabled categories above to HubSpot, even if the sender or recipient does not have records in HubSpot. Enable this setting with caution—it may create Contacts that you don't want in HubSpot. Outgoing emails sent within

title: Identify Your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP)
body: Overview If you want to lay the foundations for a successful sales strategy, you first need to identify your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP). An ICP is a fictitious company that combines the key characteristics that best portray your ideal customer. By analyzing firmographics such as company size, industry, location, annual revenue, and budget you can more easily define the types of companies that you serve best. This in turn helps you to better understand your customer’s biggest pain points, tailor your

title: Identify Your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP)
body: products or services to their needs, and focus your sales efforts on bringing in the most qualified customers so that you can reduce churn and increase Customer Lifetime Value (CLV). Any B2B business set on boosting growth, improving customer relationships, and increasing sales should identify and define their ICP. ICP Refer to the sections below for more information about the steps to follow to create your ICP and how you can apply that information to your sales campaigns within Apollo. ICP

title: Identify Your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP)
body:
Create Your Ideal Customer Profile To ensure you find, engage, and convert the right businesses for your product(s) or service(s), you need to identify the defining characteristics of your ideal customer. Start by asking yourself 5 important questions: Which of your current customers make the most out of your product(s) or service(s)?
What traits do your best customers have in common?
What recurring objections do you receive from past customers or lost opportunities?
Which customers are easiest to upsell to

title: Identify Your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP)
body:
and why?
What do the customers of your closest competitors have in common? To answer all of these questions thoroughly, you need to dive into your data and align all departments. Every team in your business can offer valuable insights that will help influence and tailor your sales strategies so that you can share the right message with the right companies at the right time. To better pinpoint what your Ideal Customer Profile looks like, follow these 4 steps: Ideal Customer Profile

title: Identify Your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP)
headings: Create Your Ideal Customer Profile > Analyze Your Existing Data
body: Analyze Your Existing Data Gather the data from your CRM and look for key trends between your customers. Categorize them by defining attributes such as industry, company size, revenue, funding, technology stack, and location. Compare these attributes with their profitability scores. Think about which customers have been with you for the longest. Is there a relationship between certain firmographics and their Customer Satisfaction (CSAT) scores? Could industry or employee headcount, for example, be impacting

title: Identify Your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP)
headings: Create Your Ideal Customer Profile > Analyze Your Existing Data
body: customer longevity? Consider which industries have the shortest and longest sales cycles. What characteristics differentiate them? Examine the main causes of customer churn. Do these companies share any defining attributes? Look for distinct patterns between all of the companies that you analyze.

title: Identify Your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP)
headings: Create Your Ideal Customer Profile > Rank Your Customers
body: Rank Your Customers When you analyze your data, create a list of your best and worst customers. Consider what makes them such a great fit or a big risk to take on. Discuss the most common objections that your Sales and Customer Success teams face regularly. Reflect on the key attributes that can lead these deals to falter. You’ll need to talk to each department to clarify the metrics that they use to set their team’s objectives and define success. This will help frame the specific attributes that you all

title: Identify Your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP)
headings: Create Your Ideal Customer Profile > Rank Your Customers
body: agree to be the most important for your company. Remember that there isn’t one “right” metric to determine the Ideal Customer Profiles for your business. What might be important to one company, is not necessarily relevant to another. You need to adapt your analysis to fit your company’s objectives. Ideal Customer Profiles One way to go about this is to rank your customers based on their CLV, ROI, and CSAT scores and then compare this data with the firmographics that you gathered at the beginning to see if

title: Identify Your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP)
headings: Create Your Ideal Customer Profile > Rank Your Customers
body: there are any distinct patterns between them. You may find that what you thought were your “best” customers do not actually bring the most benefit to your company long-term. By teaming up with other departments, you will be able to take a more holistic approach to how you define “best” and “worst.”

title: Identify Your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP)
headings: Create Your Ideal Customer Profile > Dissect Your Success
body:
Dissect Your Success Get granular. Once you have a list of your “best” and “worst” customers, don’t just analyze the data, but also the approach that you took to close and maintain these customers. The more detail you go into, the easier it will then be for you to relate to your customers and build your product or service around their needs. You can then start to hone in on the types of Personas to reach out to within your ICP. Personas ICP ICP vs. Persona
Please note, a Persona is not the same as an ICP.

title: Identify Your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP)
headings: Create Your Ideal Customer Profile > Dissect Your Success
body: To identify your ICP you need to use measurable data (such as company size and industry for B2B or age and gender for B2C) to gather information about the type of business or individual that is best suited to your company offerings. To identify your Personas, you need to use qualitative data (such as pain points, goals and personality type) to gather information about the kinds of individuals that fall within your Ideal Customer Profile. An ICP helps you to clarify who you sell to, whereas Personas help you

title: Identify Your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP)
headings: Create Your Ideal Customer Profile > Dissect Your Success
body:
to clarify how you sell to them. Both should play an important role in your sales and marketing strategies, but you cannot define your Personas without first defining your ICP. ICP vs. Persona

body: Apply Your ICP to Apollo Now that you have identified your Ideal Customer Profile, there are several ways that you can use Apollo to further tailor your sales approach to find and engage with your ideal customers.

title: Identify Your Ideal Customer Profile (ICP)
headings: Create Your Ideal Customer Profile > Apply Your ICP to Apollo > Filters
body: Filters Filters allow you to include or exclude specific subsets of data when you search for new Contacts or Accounts in Apollo. This helps you to better segment and personalize searches in Apollo so that you can find and engage with the companies that best reflect your ICP. Filters Contacts Accounts ICP As you use Apollo to hone in on your Ideal Customer Profiles, you can search using the most relevant Filters for your campaigns. body: Sequences Sequences are outreach campaigns with any number of sequential contact points and tasks that you can customize to personally engage your ideal customers at scale. They help your team communicate with your ICP and complete the right tasks at the right time to speed your prospects through your pipeline and turn them into paying customers as efficiently as possible. title: Use the Apollo REST API
body: Overview An application programming interface, or API, is a set of definitions and protocols for integrating application software. When you use an API, every request you send is a "call." A call can be something as simple as logging in or something more complex like completing an online transaction. For the Apollo API, calls are actions such as searching for companies, creating a contact, or updating the stage for a group of accounts. There are limits to the number of calls you can make, depending on your

SendGrid and SPAM Filters SendGrid replaces the tracking URLs and directs them to SendGrid servers to resolve deliverability issues. If you connect your Apollo account to SendGrid, you do not need to configure a Tracking Subdomain because SendGrid manages your tracking links on their end. For additional information, please see the "SendGrid Integration Overview" article. Tracking Subdomain SendGrid Integration Overview SendGrid and SPAM Filters
Please note, if your emails are flagged as SPAM while your

title: Set Up Apollo's Integration with SendGrid
body: Apollo account is connected to SendGrid, you may need to replace the tracking link in the emails within your SendGrid account itself. SendGrid includes a feature called Link Branding that functions the same as Apollo's Tracking Subdomain. This Link Branding feature provides the URL that you must replace to reset the deliverability on your account. In this scenario, contact SendGrid Technical Support so that they can help you update this configuration and provide any additional information about

title: Create Opportunities in Apollo
body:
Opportunities Click + New Opportunity. + New Opportunity All new Opportunities include two sections, Basics and Custom Fields Opportunities Basics Custom Fields The Basics section will always include the following fields: Basics Name: This is the name of the Opportunity. It can be anything that you choose, but it is best to keep it specific and descriptive.

Amount: This is the projected deal amount for the Opportunity before it closes. You can update this field once a deal has closed to account for the

title: Create Opportunities in Apollo
body:
actual contract amount.

Opportunity Stage: This is the stage for the Opportunity in the pipeline. The available options in the drop-down are populated by the stages you have defined in Settings.

Close Date: Once you have closed a deal based on this Opportunity, update this field with the final contract date.

Account: This is the company that is associated with the Opportunity.

Owner: This is the Apollo.io user who owns or maintains the relationship with this Account or Opportunity. Name Opportunity

title: Bi-Directional Sync Overview
body: Pricing Guide for more information. Bi-directional Sync Basic Professional Custom Apollo Pricing Guide Bi-directional Sync allows two datasets in two different systems to act as one. This kind of synchronization allows you to keep consistent data across multiple platforms. In a practical sense, it helps you prevent stale data and resolves conflicts between two platforms. Bi-directional Sync Apollo uses Bi-directional Sync to streamline your experience. Refer to the sections below to find out how Apollo

title: Bi-Directional Sync Overview
body: protects and integrates your existing contact data from your CRM with the Apollo contact database. Bi-directional Sync

title: Bi-Directional Sync Overview
headings: Overview > How Apollo Uses Bi-Directional Sync
body: How Apollo Uses Bi-Directional Sync Apollo allows you to sync contact data between your saved contacts and Hubspot or Salesforce. Use Bi-directional Sync to keep your contact data consistent between your CRM and your saved contacts from the ever-evolving Apollo database. Bi-directional Sync Since the sync is bi-directional, you can both sync your CRM to your saved contacts in Apollo and sync your saved contacts in Apollo to your CRM. Do this regularly to keep your contact data up-to-date on both platforms.

title: Bi-Directional Sync Overview
headings: Overview > How Apollo Uses Bi-Directional Sync
body:
When you sync your CRM with your saved contacts in Apollo, Apollo cross-references your data with the Apollo database and enriches any missing or inaccurate data. CRM Integration
Please note, you can only connect 1 CRM to Apollo at a time. For example, if you connect a Salesforce account to Apollo, you can't connect a Hubspot account as well. CRM Integration

title: Bi-Directional Sync Overview

body: account as well. CRM Integration Please note, you can only connect 1 CRM to Apollo at a time. For example, if you connect a Salesforce account to Apollo, you can't connect a Hubspot account as well.

title: Bi-Directional Sync Overview
headings: Overview > How Apollo Protects the Contact Database
body: How Apollo Protects the Contact Database With Bi-directional Sync, it is possible to import or export corrupt data. To protect your data and the Apollo database from data pollution, you work within your own instance of Apollo. Bi-directional Sync This means that if you import Salesforce data into your saved contacts in Apollo, users from other companies will not have access to that data. This protects your proprietary contact information and shields the Apollo database from accidental corruption. Each user

title: Bi-Directional Sync Overview
headings: Overview > How Apollo Protects the Contact Database
body: has the base instance of Apollo and can sync with Hubspot or Salesforce.

title: Use the Apollo Chrome Extension in Gmail
body: Overview The Apollo Chrome extension adds Apollo functionality to your Gmail mailbox and allows you to load templates, create follow-ups, and sync your interactions with Salesforce. Follow the steps below for detailed instructions about how to use the added Apollo functionality in your Gmail mailbox.

title: Use the Apollo Chrome Extension in Gmail
headings: Read the Doc > Load Templates in Gmail
body: Load Templates in Gmail Launch the Gmail mailbox that you have synced with Apollo. Then, click Compose. Compose Click Select Template. Select Template In the new modal, click an existing template to load it. If you do not have any templates or if you would like to create a new one, click + New. + New After you load a template, continue to tweak your email as normal. Click Send when you're finished. Send

title: Use the Apollo Chrome Extension in Gmail
headings: Read the Doc > Create a Follow-up Reminder in Gmail
body: Create a Follow-up Reminder in Gmail Launch the Gmail mailbox that you have synced with Apollo. Then, click Compose. Compose Click Follow-Up. Follow-Up In the modal, select a time and parameters for your reminder. Click Set Follow-up. Set Follow-up

title: Use the Apollo Chrome Extension in Gmail
headings: Read the Doc > Push Email Interactions to Salesforce
body: Push Email Interactions to Salesforce Launch the Gmail mailbox that you have synced with Apollo. Then, click Compose. Compose If your Apollo account is linked to Salesforce, you can launch the Salesforce modal. Click Salesforce. Salesforce Track your emails in Salesforce with the toggle. Search for the "lead" or "contact" for which you want to associate this email. Search for a "Salesforce Opportunity" for which you want to associate this email. Click Track to enable or disable email tracking. Track

title: Use the Apollo Chrome Extension in Gmail
body: Additional Settings

title: Use the Apollo Chrome Extension in Gmail
headings: Read the Doc > Additional Settings > All Accounts
body: All Accounts Launch the Gmail mailbox that you have synced with Apollo. To adjust the general mailbox settings for your synced Gmail mailbox, click Apollo next to the search bar. Apollo You can enable or disable email tracking, templates, send later, and reminders. Additionally, you can enable or disable desktop notifications. You can also enable default reminders when you do not receive a reply.

title: Use the Apollo Chrome Extension in Gmail
headings: Read the Doc > Additional Settings > Accounts With Salesforce Integrated
body: Accounts With Salesforce Integrated You can enable or disable logging for all outgoing emails to Salesforce by default. You can also automatically log emails in Salesforce to the most recent "Opportunity" for the contact's company.

title: How Do I Avoid Adding the Same Contact to Multiple Sequences?

Apollo Sequences allow you to reach out to your customers at scale. That means you may contact hundreds—or even thousands—of people at the same time. With that kind of volume, it is possible that you may accidentally add the same contact to multiple Sequences. Sequences Sequences What's All This Sequence Mumbo-Jumbo?

title: Create an Apollo Zap in Zapier
body:
Overview Zapier uses Zaps to connect apps and services together. Every Zap includes a trigger step and at least one action step. A trigger is an event that kick-starts a Zap. An action is an event that a Zap carries out. When you turn a Zap on and a trigger event takes place, Zapier automatically completes the related action steps for you. title: Email Sending Limits Overview
body: What are Sending Limits? Sending limits for emails may seem counter-intuitive to your goals, but the limits set in Apollo help protect your email accounts. Whether sending through Apollo or not, your email provider limits the number of emails that you can send if they suspect you of spamming large amounts of people you don't know. Apollo uses your personal business email accounts as "linked mailboxes." Since your email provider only lets you send a finite amount of emails at a time, your account can be

title: Email Sending Limits Overview
body: limited or suspended if you exceed their volume limits. Apollo's sending limits feature helps you avoid suspension or limitation by your email provider while helping you remain efficient.

title: Email Sending Limits Overview
body: Apollo Sending Limits Navigate to Settings->Mailboxes and find the mailbox for which you'd like to view your sending limits. Settings Mailboxes Your "Daily Limit" and "Hourly Limit" are shown to the right of the mailbox. Click the mailbox you want to edit to change the limits in the Mailbox Settings. Mailbox Settings Sending limits through Apollo count all emails sent from your linked email address and schedules any emails over the limit for the following day or hour when you max them out. Your daily

title: Email Sending Limits Overview
body:
sending limit is based on a rolling 24-hour period, not on the calendar day. Email Provider Limits and Apollo
Please note, the daily/hourly limits monitored by your email provider include all emails sent via Apollo and emails you send from the mailbox itself. If you send a high volume of emails from your email client, you should lower your limits in Apollo. Email Provider Limits and Apollo
Please note, the daily/hourly limits monitored by your email provider include all emails sent via Apollo and emails you

title: Email Sending Limits Overview
body: send from the mailbox itself. If you send a high volume of emails from your email client, you should lower your limits in Apollo. Email Provider Limits and Apollo Please note, the daily/hourly limits monitored by your email provider include all emails sent via Apollo and emails you send from the mailbox itself. If you send a high volume of emails from your email client, you should lower your limits in Apollo.

title: Email Sending Limits Overview
body: Email Provider Rate Limits Gmail, Microsoft, and all other email service providers monitor sent emails to ensure that all individual accounts are used by individuals to email other individuals. You must use efficiency applications, like Apollo, responsibly to avoid the potential of your provider limiting sending or suspending your account. A suspiciously high number of emails sent in a small period of time can be a red flag for your email provider. For example, Google Suite's hard limits are 400 emails per

title: Email Sending Limits Overview
body:
hour and 2000 emails per rolling 24 hour period. This means they never allow any of their users to send more than that number of emails via an individual mailbox. Google Suite's hard limits Sending Reputation
Please note, you must develop a sending reputation with your email service provider. To do this, send a reasonable volume of emails with a low amount of bounces and SPAM complaints. Over time, you will develop a better reputation with your email service provider and you can send a higher volume of

title: Email Sending Limits Overview
body:
emails without having your account rate-limited or suspended. Sending Reputation
Please note, you must develop a sending reputation with your email service provider. To do this, send a reasonable volume of emails with a low amount of bounces and SPAM complaints. Over time, you will develop a better reputation with your email service provider and you can send a higher volume of emails without having your account rate-limited or suspended. Sending Reputation Please note, you must develop a sending reputation

title: Email Sending Limits Overview
body: with your email service provider. To do this, send a reasonable volume of emails with a low amount of bounces and SPAM complaints. Over time, you will develop a better reputation with your email service provider and you can send a higher volume of emails without having your account rate-limited or suspended. Any new Gmail account that sends 400 emails per hour or 2000 emails per day will almost certainly get limited or suspended by Google. That amount of activity without a gradual buildup sends a clear

title: Email Sending Limits Overview
body: message to Gmail's monitoring tools that you likely opened the email account to SPAM people. Keep in mind there are many factors that come into play when Google determines your sending reputation and it's always best to play it safe.

title: Email Sending Limits Overview
body:
How to Raise Your Limits Generally, Apollo advises that you stick with the default mailbox setting of 400 emails per day and 100 per hour. If you want to increase the sending limits, you should do so gradually. Daily Limit: Increase by no more than 100 each week until you reach 1500 emails/day, which you should never go beyond if you're linked to a regular business mailbox.

Hourly Limit: Increase by no more than 20 each week until you reach 400 emails/hour. Never go beyond 400 emails/hour if you're linked

title: Email Sending Limits Overview
body:
to a regular business mailbox. Daily Limit Hourly Limit Here are other additional suggestions you can consider to send more emails as well: Link additional mailboxes to users in your Apollo account so each mailbox has its own sending limits. Apollo Professional plan allows you to add up to 2 mailboxes per user, while the Custom plan allows you to link up to 5 mailboxes per user.

Integrate with SendGrid via Apollo integrations. SendGrid allows you to send up to 6000 emails per day and 500 emails per hour.

title: Email Sending Limits Overview
body:
Link additional mailboxes Professional Custom Integrate with SendGrid SendGrid Daily Email Limits
Please note, do not set your limits higher than 2000 emails per day. For your first 30 days of sending emails with Apollo, you should not send more than 400 emails per day. If you need to send a higher volume than that, you should integrate with Sendgrid, which is a transactional email service built for even higher-volume sending. Daily Email Limits
Please note, do not set your limits higher than 2000 emails

title: Email Sending Limits Overview
body: per day. For your first 30 days of sending emails with Apollo, you should not send more than 400 emails per day. If you need to send a higher volume than that, you should integrate with Sendgrid, which is a transactional email service built for even higher-volume sending. Daily Email Limits Please note, do not set your limits higher than 2000 emails per day. For your first 30 days of sending emails with Apollo, you should not send more than 400 emails per day. If you need to send a higher volume than that,

title: Email Sending Limits Overview
body:
you should integrate with Sendgrid, which is a transactional email service built for even higher-volume sending. Sendgrid Why isn't Apollo sending out enough emails to hit my sending limit?
When you try to set a large sending limit through your default ESP without integrating SendGrid, it's possible that your ESP will not allow them to send this quantity of emails. This is because sending limits are set by your ESP and not Apollo. Apollo's configuration is a way to have some control within the platform.

title: Email Sending Limits Overview
body:
ESPs that manage this number natively and typically look to limit how many emails an account can send automatically. Why isn't Apollo sending out enough emails to hit my sending limit?
When you try to set a large sending limit through your default ESP without integrating SendGrid, it's possible that your ESP will not allow them to send this quantity of emails. title: Email Sending Limits Overview
headings: What Happens When I Hit My Limits In Apollo?
body: What Happens When I Hit My Limits In Apollo? If you hit your Apollo sending limits in a given hour or day, Apollo automatically places the emails in a queue with the "Scheduled-delayed" status until the next available time to send. The next available time could be the next business day or the next hour, depending on the situation. Please note, Apollo puts this limit in place to ensure that you do not have your email account suspended by your email service provider for sending too many emails in a given

title: Email Sending Limits Overview
headings: What Happens When I Hit My Limits In Apollo?
body: amount of time. To check on the status of your emails, hover your mouse over Engage in the navbar and then click Emails. Engage Emails From the "Emails" tab, you can see the status of your email on the right side. If the status is "Scheduled-delayed," it is likely because you hit your sending limit and the email will send at the next available time.

title: Email Sending Limits Overview
headings: What Happens When I Get Limited/Suspended by My Email Provider?
body: What Happens When I Get Limited/Suspended by My Email Provider? If you are rate limited or suspended by your email service provider, it means that you've sent too much bad content or too many emails per day or hour and you should immediately lower your sending limits in Apollo, edit the content of any emails you're sending that received a high rate of SPAM complaints, and follow any further instructions given by your email provider to get back in their good graces. title: Set Up Your Email Signature
body:
Overview Set Up Your Signature After Connecting a Mailbox
As a best practice, you should set up your email signature after you have connected a mailbox to your Apollo account. Apollo automatically copies over the signature from your email account when you add it to the platform. If you add a signature to your account before you connect a mailbox, Apollo will not replace it with a signature found in the settings for the mailbox you connect later. Intent Signals Apollo partners with the intent data provider, LeadSift (a Foundry company). LeadSift collects intent data through multiple sources, merging signals from the public web, social networks, events, job postings, technology installs, and more. Intent signals are collected by crawling the public web sources for buying behaviors and are 98% accurate with no guesswork involved. Tell Me More!

title: Buying Intent Overview
body: accounts at the right time. buying intent contacts To do so, you must first select the different keywords and competitors that you are targeting. Apollo refers to these as intent topics. When a company actively searches for one of your selected intent topics, this triggers an intent signal. Apollo captures and updates intent signals weekly. Based on the frequency, trend, and recency that these intent signals fire, Apollo calculates an intent score. intent topics intent topics intent signal intent signals

title: Buying Intent Overview
body: intent score

title: Buying Intent Overview
body:
Intent Score Apollo uses the intent score to calculate the strength of a company's buying intent. Apollo's proprietary algorithm calculates intent score based on 3 components: intent score intent score Frequency: How often is a company searching for a particular topic with intent? For example, a company triggers 3 signals within the last 3 months.

Trend: Has there been an upward or downward trend in the search for a particular intent topic over the last 30 days in comparison to the previous 30

title: Buying Intent Overview
body:
days?

Recency: When was the last time a company searched for the intent topic? For example, 1 week ago, 1 month ago, 3 months ago, etc. Frequency Trend intent topic Recency intent topic Apollo considers each of these components when giving the company a score. Apollo then groups them into 1 of 3 categories—high, medium, or low intent. High: A company triggers at least 4 intent signals in the last 90 days or demonstrates an upward trend with at least 2 intent signals in the last week.

Medium: A company

title: Buying Intent Overview
body:
triggers at least 2 intent signals in the last 90 days and at least 1 intent signal in the last two weeks.

Low: A company triggers at least 1 intent signal in the last 90 days. High intent signals intent signals Medium intent signals intent signal Low intent signal The higher a company's overall intent score, the more likely your ideal contacts within the company will engage and convert into paying customers. intent score contacts

title: Buying Intent Overview
body: Buying Intent Sources Apollo's partner, LeadSift (a Foundry company), is an industry-leading buying intent provider. LeadSift sources buying intent in several ways, including crawling millions of public web documents for buying behaviors and sourcing research-based intent from publisher sites to identify when buyers actively research relevant topics. Web documents are public sources such as social media sites, blogs, forums, research sites, and hiring boards, to name a few. buying intent buying intent Got

GDPR on the Mind?
If you are wondering about how to stay GDPR compliant, fear not! LeadSift (a Foundry company), only provides information on accounts that have shown intent to buy. This means LeadSift buying intent falls under legitimate interest and is GDPR compliant. Cue sigh of relief! Got GDPR on the Mind?

title: Connect "Team Sync" Authentication Credentials To Your Salesforce Integration
body: Overview Salesforce Team Sync authentication credentials are always applied app-wide for all users. They are used as the primary connection between Apollo and Salesforce. Team Sync Salesforce lets you configure many different levels of permissions. It is essential that the login you use for your Team Sync authentication credentials belongs to a Salesforce user with both "read and write" permissions for all of the objects and fields you're syncing to ensure that Apollo can save them successfully. Team Sync

title: Connect "Team Sync" Authentication Credentials To Your Salesforce Integration

Let's Go Play In the Sandbox!
Please note, it is possible to connect Apollo to your Salesforce sandbox account, but you must click this link to do so. As a best practice, we recommend that you create a new or separate Apollo instance to connect your sandbox. Then, once you're ready to link your actual Salesforce account to Apollo, you can do so in your regular Apollo instance. title: Set Up a Custom Tracking Subdomain (URL)
body: Overview A Tracking Domain is a secondary (or sub) domain name related to your original domain. It allows Apollo to redirect a tracking pixel added to emails to track opens, clicks, and unsubscribes. Tracking Domain Tracking pixels are often flagged as SPAM. To improve the delivery rates for the emails you send through Apollo, you can set up a custom Tracking Subdomain. Tracking Subdomain Refer to the sections below for more information about how to create, connect, and manage a new Tracking Subdomain.

If your tracking subdomain is Healthy, it means that your recipients’ email servers are not flagging your emails as SPAM. When you check your email statistics in Apollo, you should see high open rates and low bounce rates. If your tracking subdomain is Unhealthy, it means that your recipients’ email servers are flagging your emails as SPAM. Tracking Subdomain Status

title: Create Custom Contact Fields
body: Overview Custom fields allow you to capture individualized research about a contact, account, or user and leverage them in Apollo sequence email templates for open-time personalization. Custom Contact fields allow you to capture information about individual people so you can easily re-use it in a template. Custom Contact Refer to the section below for additional details about how to create custom fields for contacts.

title: Create Custom Contact Fields
body:
Create a Custom Contact Field Launch Apollo and then click Settings. Settings Click Contacts. Contacts Click Custom Fields. Custom Fields Click + New Field. + New Field On the "Add Custom Contact Field" modal, type a descriptive name in the Name text-box. Name Select the field Type from the drop-down. Type The available field types include: Field Name
Description


Single-line text
Allows you to include a single line of text for the contact field. You must specify the maximum number of characters for the

title: Create Custom Contact Fields
body:
field.


Multi-line text
Allows you to include a string of text that spans multiple lines. You must specify the maximum number of characters for the field. Line breaks count against the total character count.


Number
Allows you to include a number with or without decimals. You cannot use non-numeric characters.


Date
Allows you to type a date in the format of Day/Month/Year or select a date with the calendar widget.


Date/Time
Allows you to type a date in the format of Day/Month/Year or select a date

title: Create Custom Contact Fields
body:
with the calendar widget. Allows you to select a time in half-hour increments from the drop-down.


Checkbox
Allows you to specify either True or False within the field's drop-down.


Picklist
Allows you to include an existing picklist or create a new picklist with defined values. You can only select one value from the picklist. For additional information about creating picklists, please see  Create Global Picklists.

title: Improve Your CSV Data With CSV Enrichment
body: Overview Marketing teams and sales managers with large lists of contacts need the ability to easily keep them up to date for effective segmentation and targeted engagement. Apollo's CSV Enrichment feature allows you to add available contact from Apollo's database directly to a CSV file. This is a great way to leverage the vast amount of data available in Apollo in other systems that you use every day, but have not directly integrated with Apollo. CSV Enrichment works for both people and companies.

title: Improve Your CSV Data With CSV Enrichment
body:
Limitations and Specifications Apollo supports CSV files with a maximum size of 1,000 total rows. Files with more than 1,000 rows will cause an error. You will need to split the CSV into separate smaller files with fewer than 1,000 rows. The CSV Enrichment feature is available to all pricing tiers with the following limitations: Pricing Tier

Please note, the unsubscribe link that Apollo attaches to your emails expires 47 days after you send an email. If a contact attempts to click the link after the 47-day period, the URL will not be valid. They Snooze, They Lose!

Overview There are certain scenarios when one contact may match multiple accounts in your CRM or in Apollo. For example, if you have purposeful duplicates. If this applies to you, Apollo provides you with 2 options: Receive a prompt to decide which of the related accounts you want to map a contact to. title: Configure Your Salesforce "Pull" Settings
body: Overview Once your Salesforce account is connected to Apollo, you can configure the way that Apollo pulls data into the platform from Salesforce. Refer to the section below for information about how to configure the pull settings for Salesforce contacts/leads, accounts, opportunities, and tasks.

title: Configure Your Salesforce "Pull" Settings
body: Access Your Salesforce Integration Settings Launch Apollo and click Settings. Settings Click Integrations. Integrations Click View under the Salesforce integration. View You can now configure the various Salesforce integration settings.

Accounts
Opportunities
Tasks Contacts/Leads Accounts Opportunities Tasks

title: Configure Your Salesforce "Pull" Settings
headings: Access Your Salesforce Integration Settings > Configure "Pull Records" Settings > Contacts/Leads
body:
Salesforce contacts pulled into Apollo should automatically be matched to accounts/companies in Apollo. Contacts Vs. Leads
Please note that when Apollo pulls a contact from Salesforce, Apollo respects the specific account assigned to it in Salesforce. For example, if you have duplicate accounts for Example.io in Salesforce, Apollo pulls those duplicates into Apollo and associates the contact with the right duplicate using the Salesforce account ID.
However, Salesforce leads do not have accounts with which

title: Configure Your Salesforce "Pull" Settings
headings: Access Your Salesforce Integration Settings > Configure "Pull Records" Settings > Contacts/Leads
body:
to pull into Apollo by default. This means that Apollo randomly assigns a lead pulled from Salesforce to any account that matches the domain for that lead. For example, if a lead's email is joansmith@example.io and you have more than 1 Example.io account in your Salesforce instance, Apollo randomly assigns the lead to one of those Example.io accounts. Contacts Vs. Leads
Please note that when Apollo pulls a contact from Salesforce, Apollo respects the specific account assigned to it in Salesforce. For

title: Configure Your Salesforce "Pull" Settings
headings: Access Your Salesforce Integration Settings > Configure "Pull Records" Settings > Contacts/Leads
body:
example, if you have duplicate accounts for Example.io in Salesforce, Apollo pulls those duplicates into Apollo and associates the contact with the right duplicate using the Salesforce account ID.
However, Salesforce leads do not have accounts with which to pull into Apollo by default. title: Create Custom Account Fields
body: Overview Custom fields allow you to capture individualized research about a contact, account, or user and leverage them in Apollo sequence email templates for open-time personalization. Custom Account fields allow you to capture information about individual companies so you can easily re-use it in a template. Custom Account Refer to the section below for additional details about how to create custom fields for accounts.

title: CSV Enrichment Reports Overview
body: Overview CSV Enrichment Reports provide you with a high-level overview of how well Apollo did at enriching the contacts in a CSV that you uploaded. CSV Enrichment Reports Refer to the sections below to learn how to access CSV Enrichment Reports and better understand what data is available within them. CSV Enrichment Reports

title: CSV Enrichment Reports Overview
body: Access CSV Enrichment Reports Launch Apollo and click Enrich. Enrich Click CSV Enrichment. CSV Enrichment Click View Report for the enriched CSV file that you want to analyze. View Report When you're done analyzing the CSV Enrichment Report, click Back to Listing to return to the list of enriched CSV files. CSV Enrichment Report Back to Listing

title: CSV Enrichment Reports Overview
body: CSV Enrichment Report Features There are several components to the CSV Enrichment Report. Each section is described in detail below.

title: CSV Enrichment Reports Overview
headings: CSV Enrichment Report Features > Records Enriched
body:
Records Enriched The Records Enriched section displays the total number of CSV records submitted to Apollo in a pie graph. This graph is segmented by "Matched Records," "Duplicate Records," and "Not Found." Records Enriched Matched Records: The number of CSV records that Apollo could match to the database

Duplicate Records: The number of duplicate records in the CSV

Not Found: The number of CSV records that Apollo could not match to the database Matched Records Duplicate Records Not Found Hover your mouse

title: CSV Enrichment Reports Overview
headings: CSV Enrichment Report Features > Records Enriched
body: over an individual segment to see the number of records for that segment.

title: CSV Enrichment Reports Overview
headings: CSV Enrichment Report Features > Completeness Score
body: Completeness Score The Completeness Score section of the CSV Enrichment Report provides a "before and after" snapshot of your CSV data based on the number of individual data points found in the CSV before and after enrichment. Within the bar chart, the "Before" bar shows the percentage of available fields that were completed within the CSV prior to enrichment. The "After" bar shows the percentage of fields completed after Apollo enriched the CSV. Completeness Score CSV Enrichment Report

title: CSV Enrichment Reports Overview
headings: CSV Enrichment Report Features > Enrichment Result
body: Enrichment Result The Enrichment Result section provides you with a bar chart view of the data. The left bar ("Total Fields Enriched") reflects the number of enriched columns over the total number of columns in the CSV. The right bar (Total Data Points) reflects the total number of enriched data points over the total number of possible data points. Enrichment Result

title: CSV Enrichment Reports Overview
headings: CSV Enrichment Report Features > Matched Fields
body:
Matched Fields The Matched Fields section provides you with an overview of the fields that you mapped during the upload process. The first bar provides you with the number of fields that you mapped during this process. The second bar provides you with the total number of mapped CSV fields that Apollo was able to match values from. The third bar provides you with the total number of mapped CSV fields that Apollo could not match values from. Matched Fields Why do I have "Unmatched Fields?"
Typically,

title: CSV Enrichment Reports Overview
headings: CSV Enrichment Report Features > Matched Fields
body:
"Unmatched Fields" result from fields mapped incorrectly during the upload process. For example, if you mapped your CSV's "Title" column to Apollo's "First Name" field, Apollo would not be able to match any values for it. Why do I have "Unmatched Fields?"
Typically, "Unmatched Fields" result from fields mapped incorrectly during the upload process. For example, if you mapped your CSV's "Title" column to Apollo's "First Name" field, Apollo would not be able to match any values for it. Why do I have

title: CSV Enrichment Reports Overview
headings: CSV Enrichment Report Features > Matched Fields
body: "Unmatched Fields?" Typically, "Unmatched Fields" result from fields mapped incorrectly during the upload process. For example, if you mapped your CSV's "Title" column to Apollo's "First Name" field, Apollo would not be able to match any values for it.

title: CSV Enrichment Reports Overview
headings: CSV Enrichment Report Features > Emails Enriched
body:
Emails Enriched The Emails Enriched section provides you with the total number of records (rows) in your CSV. It is displayed as a pie graph and is segmented by rows enriched with "Verified" email addresses, rows enriched with "Not Verified" email addresses, and rows where an email address was "Not Found." Emails Enriched Verified: The total number of verified emails that Apollo matched to the records in the CSV

Not Verified: The total number of unverified emails that Apollo matched to the records in the

title: CSV Enrichment Reports Overview
headings: CSV Enrichment Report Features > Emails Enriched
body:
CSV

Not found: The total number of records for which Apollo could not find an email Verified Not Verified Not found Hover your mouse over an individual segment to see the number of records for that segment.

title: CSV Enrichment Reports Overview
headings: CSV Enrichment Report Features > Phone Numbers Enriched
body: Phone Numbers Enriched The Phone Numbers Enriched section provides you with two fields. The first bar reflects the total number of enriched company-headquarter phone numbers ("HQ Phone"). The second bar reflects the total number of mobile numbers enriched in the CSV ("Direct Dial"). Phone Numbers Enriched

title: CSV Enrichment Reports Overview
headings: CSV Enrichment Report Features > All Enrichment Fields
body: All Enrichment Fields The All Enrichment Fields section provides you with the total number of enriched data points for each enriched field (column) in the CSV. All Enrichment Fields

title: Supported Email Service Providers (ESPs)
body:
Apollo's mailbox functionality works best with Gmail, but supports a variety of other providers with the aid of a third-party provider, Nylas Mail. Currently, Nylas Mail supports: Microsoft Exchange
Office 365
Outlook
Yahoo!
Custom email accounts/servers POP/POP3 Mailboxes Are Not Supported
Nylas Mail, Apollo's third-party provider for non-Gmail email syncs, does not support connecting to mailbox accounts via POP/POP3. The vast majority of mail providers who support POP3 also support the IMAP standard and

title: Supported Email Service Providers (ESPs)
body:
can connect to Apollo that way. Nylas Mail also supports the SMTP standard. POP/POP3 Mailboxes Are Not Supported
Nylas Mail, Apollo's third-party provider for non-Gmail email syncs, does not support connecting to mailbox accounts via POP/POP3. The vast majority of mail providers who support POP3 also support the IMAP standard and can connect to Apollo that way. Nylas Mail also supports the SMTP standard. POP/POP3 Mailboxes Are Not Supported Nylas Mail, Apollo's third-party provider for non-Gmail email

title: Supported Email Service Providers (ESPs)
body:
syncs, does not support connecting to mailbox accounts via POP/POP3. The vast majority of mail providers who support POP3 also support the IMAP standard and can connect to Apollo that way. Nylas Mail also supports the SMTP standard. Nylas does not currently support large transactional sending services like Mandrill or Amazon SES. For that reason, Apollo cannot support linking to those services through Nylas. High-Volume Emails
If you need to send larger-volume emails than Apollo's recommended safe sending

title: Supported Email Service Providers (ESPs)
body:
limits, you should integrate your linked mailbox, whether it is Gmail, Microsoft Exchange, Office 365, Outlook, Yahoo!, or a custom email account, with Sendgrid. Click here for instructions. High-Volume Emails
If you need to send larger-volume emails than Apollo's recommended safe sending limits, you should integrate your linked mailbox, whether it is Gmail, Microsoft Exchange, Office 365, Outlook, Yahoo!, or a custom email account, with Sendgrid. Click here for instructions. High-Volume Emails If you need

title: Prospect with Personal and Business Emails
body:
Overview Apollo categorizes emails into 2 types: Business: the email address that a contact uses specifically for work purposes. For example: contactnameexample@apollo.io


Personal: the email address that a contact uses for private affairs outside of working hours. For example: contactnameexample252@gmail.com Business contact contactnameexample@apollo.io Personal contact contactnameexample252@gmail.com By default, Apollo sets your Primary email to Business. However, your industry, ideal customer profiles,

title: Prospect with Personal and Business Emails
body:
and campaign objectives, among other factors, will often dictate the type of email address that best fits your prospecting needs. For example, if you are in the recruiting industry, you are more likely to need a contact's personal email. If you sell to a B2B market, you are more likely to engage with a contact through their business email. Primary Business contact contact GDPR Has the Last Word!
Please note, you cannot access the personal emails of contacts from the EU, UK, and Switzerland due to GDPR

title: Prospect with Personal and Business Emails
body:
restrictions. Keep calm and keep compliant. GDPR Has the Last Word!

Change Your Primary Email Type Change is Good!
You can change your Primary email at any time, provided you are a superuser/admin. However, please note that Apollo only applies the new Primary email type to the Net New contacts that you request. Apollo does not change the Primary email for any existing saved contacts. This means that you can change your email type with peace of mind, knowing that you won't disrupt the contacts that you have already enrolled in a Sequence.

title: Are Action Items in Sequences Subject to My Sequence Sending Schedule?
body:
Yes, Action Items in your Sequences are subject to your sending schedule and are dictated by the Wait Time between steps. Action Items Sequences Wait Time In the below example, the Wait Time is 5 minutes. That means if there is no reply after 5 minutes, the action item takes effect. Wait Time Your Schedule
Please note, if you send an automatic email on Monday at 4.57pm and your Sending Schedule is Monday-Friday, with a Wait Time of 5 minutes, your action item won’t take effect until Tuesday morning at

9.02am. For more information about sequence schedules, please refer to the "Create and Edit Sequence Sending Schedules" article. Your Schedule

title: Improve Your Data With API Enrichment
body:
Overview Enrichment allows you to leverage Apollo's data to improve the accuracy of your contact and account information. You can use the Apollo Enrichment feature through our REST API. Each use of enrichment costs a credit if Apollo locates a valid email address in the database. Please see the Apollo pricing guide for more information. Apollo pricing guide Saved Records
Please note, Apollo does not save any returned information through the enrichment endpoint within the platform. Any returned information

title: Configure Your Salesforce "Push" Settings
body: Overview Once your Salesforce account is connected to Apollo, you can configure the way that Apollo pushes data from the platform into Salesforce. Refer to the section below for information about how to configure the push settings for Salesforce contacts/leads, accounts, opportunities, activities, tasks, meetings, and notes.

title: Configure Your Salesforce "Push" Settings
body: Access Your Salesforce Integration Settings Launch Apollo and click Settings. Settings Click Integrations. Integrations Click View under the Salesforce integration. View You can now configure the various Salesforce integration settings.

title: Configure Your Salesforce "Push" Settings
headings: Access Your Salesforce Integration Settings > Configure "Push Records" Settings
body:
Configure "Push Records" Settings From the "Salesforce Integration Setup" page, click Not Started under "Push Records." Not Started On the "Push Records to Salesforce" page there are 4 tabs to configure the various items that Apollo can pull from Salesforce. Contacts/Leads
Accounts
Opportunities
Activities, Tasks, Meetings, and Notes

title: Create a Persona
body: Overview Personas are sets of titles, seniorities, and departments that define different groups of people that you can target within key accounts. This allows you to find contacts faster with Apollo's Search tool, receive better recommendations, and improve analytics. Search Refer to the section below to learn how to create a persona.

title: Create a Persona
body:
Create a Persona Launch Apollo and click Search. Search Expand the Personas accordion in the "Filters" section on the left and then click Create a Persona. Personas Create a Persona In the modal that appears, click More under the fields to expand your filter options. More Give your persona a name in the top field and fill in the other fields to narrow your search. Click Save Persona when you're done. Save Persona Not Giving in to Granularity
When you fill in fields manually, it's a good idea to include

title: Create a Persona

multiple versions of the same title as a catch-all. For example, to search for a Chief Marketing Officer, you should include both "Chief Marketing Officer" and "CMO." Using less granular terms will yield more results. Not Giving in to Granularity

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
body: What is GDPR? The General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) is a privacy regulation enacted by the European Union (EU) in April of 2016 to protect member country citizens and their right to privacy and control over their personal data in the digital world. General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) The internet and the way we use it have changed a lot since the first privacy laws were created in the 90s. It is the EU’s hypothesis that allowing citizens more control over their digital footprint will foster

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
body:
more trust in online business. This should increase the citizens' likelihood of conducting business with them and thereby increase the digital economy. The regulation went into effect on May 25, 2018, and the potential financial penalties for failure to comply are steep. The sections below provide a high-level overview of important terms, impacts, and how Apollo participates in GDPR. GDPR Legislation
If you would like to read the actual text for the General Data Protection Regulation in its most recent

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
body:
form, please visit EU GDPR website. GDPR Legislation
If you would like to read the actual text for the General Data Protection Regulation in its most recent form, please visit EU GDPR website. GDPR Legislation If you would like to read the actual text for the General Data Protection Regulation in its most recent form, please visit EU GDPR website. EU GDPR

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
body: Why is GDPR important? GDPR is important because it likely affects many people more than they realize. The safest assumption to make is that GDPR affects your company in at least some capacity, especially if you work for a company established in the EU, a company that sells to people within the EU, or a company that monitors the actions of citizens of the EU regardless of where your headquarters is or where you send marketing emails from. Failure to adhere to GDPR guidelines can be expensive. The highest

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
body: amount a single company could pay is 4% of their global annual turnover or 20 million euros, whichever is higher. Lower-tiered fines apply to lower-level penalties and can be the equivalent of 2% of global turnover or 10 million euros. higher

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
body:
GDPR Terminology Glossary Use the glossary below to help make sense of the important terms contained in the GDPR. Consent: Contacts in the EU must provide explicit permission before you can contact them. If contact information was gained through a third party, the source must be specified at first contact with the Data Subject.

Cross-Border Data Transfer: Sending data and/or personal information outside of EU/EAA borders

Data Subject: A natural person and citizen of the EU whose information has been

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
body:
collected and can be identified by a data controller.

Data Controller: Controllers include parties who manage personal data or collect personal data. Apollo and Apollo's customers are considered data controllers.

Data Portability: A data subject’s right to their own personal data from the data controller in a familiar, machine-readable format

Data Processor: A party that is instructed by the controller in how personal data should be handled and used. Apollo is also considered a data processor.

Data

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
body:
Subject Rights: New rights within the GDPR include the right to be forgotten, the right to data portability, and the right to object to profiling.

GDPR Articles: The GDPR includes two sections—the recitals and the Articles. The Articles include the text of the legislation and the Privacy Management Activities (PMAs) that are required for compliance.

Personal Data: Personal data included in Apollo typically includes name, company address, company phone number, email address, and IP address.

Privacy by

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
body: Design and Default: Companies have an obligation to keep data privacy top-of-mind throughout the design process and to build default and adequate privacy controls into all new features. Consent Cross-Border Data Transfer Data Subject Data Controller Data Portability Data Processor Data Subject Rights GDPR Articles Personal Data Privacy by Design and Default

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
body:
GDPR's Effect On Sales Teams A key element of the GDPR that can cause business friction is the gravity of consent that is required from individuals. Specifically, in order to collect and handle (or to “process”) personal data of Europeans, marketers, and services like Apollo must have a “legal basis.” Two common legal bases include: Consent of the data subject
A “legitimate interest” to use the data that is not outweighed by fundamental “rights and freedoms,” taking into account data subjects’ “reasonable

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
body: expectations” of how data may be used The GDPR cites “direct marketing” as an example of a likely “legitimate interest.” Many legal commentators have noted that the GDPR leaves many questions unanswered and the potential for courts to resolve those questions in the years to come. Based on the best legal interpretations as of today, Apollo (and many others) believe that under this balancing test, most B2B marketing like newsletters and most direct marketing is protected as a “legitimate interest” if executed

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
body: in a thoughtful way. On the other hand, campaigns that are not targeted in a way that is likely to be useful to someone given their industry or position may not fit a “legitimate interest.” It will, therefore, be more important than ever for B2B marketers to use data wisely and tailor campaigns and marketing to be relevant. These elements are also only relevant for prospects located in the EU so you don't need to worry about any of these regulations if you’re emailing anyone outside the GDPR’s jurisdiction.

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
headings: How does Apollo adhere to GDPR?
body: How does Apollo adhere to GDPR? The Apollo team works hard to ensure that we remain in compliance for both the company's benefit as well as that of our customers. The Apollo platform is more complex in the way that it handles data than most, so our compliance is similarly complicated. Our Privacy Policy and Terms of Service include our Data Processing Addendum. The addendum helps users control what we do with their data and gives them the freedom to access and/or remove their data from our system if they so

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
headings: How does Apollo adhere to GDPR?
body: desire, among other rights. Privacy Policy Privacy Policy Terms of Service Terms of Service Data Processing Addendum Much of maintaining GDPR compliance as a vendor involves how we secure our data. In order to maintain a high bar of security we have completed the following: Apollo has achieved a SOC 2 and ISO 27001 security accreditation report. These accreditations evaluate Apollo controls that are relevant to data security, availability, and confidentiality. To gain them, Apollo needed to prove the

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
headings: How does Apollo adhere to GDPR?
body:
success of our controls and their ability to maintain security, availability, and confidentiality over a predetermined span of time.
Apollo has implemented advanced data controls, which include the encryption of all user data, which is designed to protect our customers’ data from leaks and malicious intent. The Apollo team regularly tests our product to fix any potential problems and maintains the industry’s highest standards in information security.
Apollo has built and follows data incident response

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
headings: How does Apollo adhere to GDPR?
body:
processes. These processes are tested each year for continued effectiveness.
Apollo built processes to supplement data recovery and integrity to help any customers whose data is lost or unintentionally corrupted.
Apollo has systems in place to protect all customers' rights to their own data footprint in the platform.
Apollo’s key data sub-processors, such as Amazon Web Services (AWS) and Google Cloud Platform, all have achieved similarly high-level security standards (SOC 2 and/or ISO 27001 certifications,

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
headings: How does Apollo adhere to GDPR?
body: where possible) and have undergone rigorous security evaluations. GDPR lays out different requirements for “Processors” and “Controllers” of data. In Apollo's case, we operate as both a data controller and data processor since we help our users acquire data as a controller and communicate with prospects as a processor.

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
headings: How does Apollo adhere to GDPR? > Apollo's Adherence to GDPR as Data “Controllers”
body: Apollo's Adherence to GDPR as Data “Controllers” As it stands, Apollo is in compliance as a data controller by the standards contained in the GDPR. Apollo manages the data we collect to ensure it is in compliance. We also view it as our responsibility to educate everyone who uses our data to keep them informed and prepared to use our data in a way that similarly keeps them in compliance. Our users have the option of excluding citizens of member countries within the EU to help protect themselves against

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
headings: How does Apollo adhere to GDPR? > Apollo's Adherence to GDPR as Data “Controllers”
body: accidentally emailing someone they shouldn’t. This prevents our customers from having to comb through lists of prospects to double-check their own compliance while prospecting. Apollo customers that sell or market to EU citizens must be transparent in their intentions with any personal data that they collect and must have consent from individuals before sending them any information. If they do send any form of communication, they must also provide the ability for people to opt out of any future messages. If

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
headings: How does Apollo adhere to GDPR? > Apollo's Adherence to GDPR as Data “Controllers”
body: our customers also use Apollo as their sales engagement platform, they have the ability to include opt-out links within their emails. Apollo has the ability to enrich data pertaining to citizens of the EU should our users already possess their contact information. For example, if a user has the email address and name of an individual working for L’Oréal Paris, we have the ability to enrich title and company information. With that said, this ability is only applicable if the enrichment is for the purpose of

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
headings: How does Apollo adhere to GDPR? > Apollo's Adherence to GDPR as Data “Controllers”
body: data hygiene and cleanliness or if you have a good faith reason to believe that the recipient has a demonstrated interest in receiving the information or offer, such as information that would help them perform their job. As data controllers, Apollo maintains our own compliance and aids users with their own compliance, but Apollo highly recommends that all of our customers familiarize themselves with the regulations and seek out additional support from privacy advisors if any questions remain.

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
headings: How does Apollo adhere to GDPR? > Apollo's Adherence to GDPR as Data “Processors”
body:
Apollo's Adherence to GDPR as Data “Processors” Beyond the precautions and measures laid out above, Apollo has completed and will undertake the following actions to maintain compliance as a data processor: Working with our legal counsel (and when requested, those of our customers) to ensure full preparation and compliance.
Evaluating every use case within our platform to help back up every decision we make should they face legal scrutiny.
Crafting internal workflows to quickly and thoroughly complete data

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
headings: How does Apollo adhere to GDPR? > Apollo's Adherence to GDPR as Data “Processors”
body:
subject requests
Conducting an in-depth review of all requirements implications for data processors and where we may be a joint controller
Updating all contact information and notices so data subjects and customer data controllers may contact us if necessary
Obtaining all resources necessary for ongoing compliance requirements and documentation necessitated by GDPR
Updating and maintaining data security standards and workflows to meet all requirements necessitated by GDPR
Evaluating all customer contracts

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
headings: How does Apollo adhere to GDPR? > Apollo's Adherence to GDPR as Data “Processors”
body: where necessary to ensure we’ve laid out a path for legal compliance for them to the best of our ability and to clearly detail our own responsibilities to avoid any possible confusion that could result in a penalty. We are aware that laws and regulations could continue to change, so we will continue the work of maintaining compliance and will help our customers do the same. When in doubt, your best course of action is to talk to attorneys well-versed in the data-privacy space or with a data-specific

title: General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR) Overview
headings: How does Apollo adhere to GDPR? > Apollo's Adherence to GDPR as Data “Processors”
body: officer. For all Apollo-related questions, we’re more than happy to help.

title: Configure the Dialer
headings: Get An Apollo Phone Number > Configure Calls > Types of Calls
body: Types of Calls There are two types of call options you can configure for your outgoing and incoming calls, Bridge and VoIP. Bridge VoIP Bridge allows you to consolidate calls to your mobile device while retaining the ability to log and record them in Apollo. If you enable Bridge calls for outgoing or incoming phone calls, you must enter your personal phone number. Bridge calls are only available for US phone numbers. International dialing is not supported with Bridge. Bridge Bridge Bridge Bridge Incoming

Outgoing Calls: You will receive a call to your personal phone number from your Apollo number. This call will prompt you to complete the bridge by interacting with your dialer. This sends the given contact a phone call from your Apollo number. Incoming Calls Outgoing Calls Bridged Calls

title: Automatically Create and Map Stages Between Salesforce and Apollo
body:
Overview While you can always manually map stages between Apollo and Salesforce, you can also make use of automapping to make the job easier. If an unmapped stage in Apollo matches an unmapped value in Salesforce, then Apollo can automatically map the two together. Additionally, for Salesforce values that don’t have a matching stage in the platform, Apollo will create one for you. Unmapped Stages Only
Please note, Apollo will not overwrite any mappings that you created before running the auto-mapping

feature. Apollo will only automatically map stages that are not already mapped. Unmapped Stages Only

Mark subsequent emails for that account as Not Sent

Delay subsequent emails sending for that account Delay subsequent emails sending for that account The

body: Other Settings The "Other Settings" section of the ruleset offers a few optional controls. The first textbox allows you to set the maximum number of emails sent to an individual contact in a rolling 24 hour period. title: Add, Deactivate, and Reactivate Users
body: users and their roles, you must have Administration account privileges. Please refer to the User Role Guide if you have questions about permission levels. Administration Apollo provides a robust set of controls to limit who can undertake which actions within the platform. This gives you the ability to employ the principle of least privilege for your team to make sure that everyone can undertake the actions they need in order to be successful without burdening them with the things they don't need. The

title: Add, Deactivate, and Reactivate Users
body: sections below provide high level instructions on how to add users to your Apollo account, deactivate users, and reactivate previously deactivated users.

title: Add, Deactivate, and Reactivate Users
headings: Add Users To Your Apollo Account
body: Add Users To Your Apollo Account Launch Apollo and click Settings. Settings Click Users. Users Click + New User. + New User Add the new user's First Name, Last Name, Title, and Email to the appropriate text boxes. First Name Last Name Title Email Select the user's Permission Profile from the drop down. Permission Profile If applicable, select the user's Territory and Team from their respective drop downs. Territory Team When you're finished, click Create. Create The user is now created.

title: Add, Deactivate, and Reactivate Users
headings: Deactivate Users In Your Apollo Account
body: Deactivate Users In Your Apollo Account Launch Apollo and click Settings. Settings Click Users. Users Click the additional options (...) button next to the user that you want to deactivate. Click Deactivate. Deactivate In the new modal, click Deactivate again to confirm that you want to deactivate this user or Cancel to return to the "Current User" screen. Deactivate Cancel The user is now deactivated.

title: Add, Deactivate, and Reactivate Users
headings: Reactivate Users In Your Apollo Account
body: Reactivate Users In Your Apollo Account Launch Apollo and click Settings. Settings Click Users. Users Click the additional options (...) button next to the user that you want to reactivate. Click Reactivate. Reactivate In the new modal, click + Reactivate to confirm that you want to reactivate this user or Cancel to return to the "Current User" screen. + Reactivate Cancel The user is now reactivated.

title: Use Stage Triggers to​ Manage and Track Sales Engagement
body: Stage Triggers are events in Sequences that automatically change the state of a Contact or Account. For example, you can set a trigger to change a Contact's stage to Approaching when your email to them is delivered, and then change their stage to Replied when they reply. Stage Triggers Sequences Contact Account Contact's Approaching Replied Refer to the steps below to create and edit different types of triggers.

title: Use Stage Triggers to​ Manage and Track Sales Engagement
body: Trigger Conditions A condition needs to be met at each Contact Stage before the trigger activates. Refer to the list below for the different conditions. Contact Stage

title: Use Stage Triggers to​ Manage and Track Sales Engagement
body:
Email Trigger Conditions Prospect Created: The initial stage for Contacts when you add them to your Apollo Account. This is generally done with Lead Requests, CSV uploads, or integration with your CRM.

The recommended setting for this stage is "Not Interested."



Email Delivered: A Contact receives an email. This is only delivery, and not to whether or not the email is opened.

The recommended setting for this stage is "Approaching."



Email Bounced: An email to the Contact bounces.

The recommended

title: Use Stage Triggers to​ Manage and Track Sales Engagement
body:
setting for this stage is "Bad Data" or "No Email."



Prospect Unsubscribed: A Contact opts out of email contact. This happens if you turn on unsubscribe links in your emails in your User Settings.

This stage should always be set to "Do Not Contact."



Prospect Replied: A Contact responds to an email you sent.

The recommended setting for this stage is "Replied," but your success metrics may differ.



Appointment or Email Marked as Interested: You book a meeting with a Contact or they're marked as

title: Use Stage Triggers to​ Manage and Track Sales Engagement
body:
"Interested" in a sequence.

The recommended setting for this stage is "Interested."



Unresponsive: A Contact does not respond, but you may want to reach out to them again later.

The recommended setting for this stage is "Unresponsive." Prospect Created Contacts The recommended setting for this stage is "Not Interested." Email Delivered Contact The recommended setting for this stage is "Approaching." Email Bounced Contact The recommended setting for this stage is "Bad Data" or "No Email." Prospect

title: Use Stage Triggers to​ Manage and Track Sales Engagement
body: Unsubscribed Contact User Settings This stage should always be set to "Do Not Contact." always Prospect Replied Contact The recommended setting for this stage is "Replied," but your success metrics may differ. Appointment or Email Marked as Interested Contact The recommended setting for this stage is "Interested." Unresponsive Contact The recommended setting for this stage is "Unresponsive."

title: Create Permission Profiles
body:
Overview Many different types of users on your team may use Apollo. Every user may need to undertake different responsibilities in the platform and for that reason, it is important to utilize the principle of least privilege. Apollo offers very granular permission levels that you can save as Permission Profiles and apply to individual users in your account. principle of least privilege Permission Profiles Default Permission Set
Please note, Apollo uses "Admin" as the default permission profile in the

title: Create Permission Profiles
body: Create a New Permission Profile Launch Apollo and then click Settings. Settings Click Permission Profiles. Permission Profiles Click + New Profile. + New Profile Give the Permission Profile a name and then click Create. Create The Permission Profile screen provides you with settings divided into several different sections: "Name," "Administration," "Sequence & Emails," "Lead Gen," "Accounts & Contacts," and "Territories," "Opportunities," and "Playbooks."

Rotation
Please note, if you select the Add contact to sequence action and want to improve your email deliverability, you may want to select the "round robin" option. This allows you to send emails from multiple users in your Apollo instance. Apollo then evenly distributes the number of emails sent per selected user.
Alternatively, you can choose to "rotate your mailbox." This means that Apollo divides the total number of emails evenly between all the mailboxes connected to your personal Apollo account.
If

Apollo also evenly distributes the number of emails sent from each of the user's connected mailboxes. For example, let's say you select 3 users to "round robin" and each user has 2 connected mailboxes. If you send 60 emails from this play, each user will send out 20 emails—10 from 1 mailbox and 10 from the other. Improve Your

title: Create a Sequence
body: Overview Sequences are outreach campaigns with any number of sequential contact points and tasks that are customized to personally engage your target audiences at scale. They help your team deliver communications to your customers and complete the right tasks at the right time to speed your prospects through your pipeline and turn them into paying customers as efficiently as possible. Sequences
