If contacts already exist in Apollo What criteria does Apollo use to match people already in Apollo to people in a CSV file?
When you update an existing record in Apollo via CSV, Apollo uses 3

title: Upload a CSV of Contacts to Apollo
body:
sets of unique identifiers in order of most to least unique. Those identifiers include:

linkedin_URL

first_name + last_name + organization

email address

This means, if you include linkedin_URL, you can update all of the other data for a person. If you include first_name + last_name + organization, but you do not include a different linkedin_URL, you can update email address and other data. If you include only email_address and you do not include the linkedin_URL or first_name + last_name + organization,

title: Upload a CSV of Contacts to Apollo
body:
then you can only update other fields for the people in your file.
If you opt to update existing records in Apollo from your CSV, Apollo only updates records that have a matching email address, a matching name (first and last), and a matching company. You can also opt to skip updating duplicate records.
When duplicate people exist in your CSV, Apollo only accepts the highest row in the file to update the record in the platform. What criteria does Apollo use to match people already in Apollo to people in a

title: Upload a CSV of Contacts to Apollo
body:
CSV file?
When you update an existing record in Apollo via CSV, Apollo uses 3 sets of unique identifiers in order of most to least unique. Those identifiers include:

linkedin_URL

first_name + last_name + organization

email address

This means, if you include linkedin_URL, you can update all of the other data for a person. If you include first_name + last_name + organization, but you do not include a different linkedin_URL, you can update email address and other data. If you include only email_address and

title: Upload a CSV of Contacts to Apollo
body:
you do not include the linkedin_URL or first_name + last_name + organization, then you can only update other fields for the people in your file.
If you opt to update existing records in Apollo from your CSV, Apollo only updates records that have a matching email address, a matching name (first and last), and a matching company. You can also opt to skip updating duplicate records.
When duplicate people exist in your CSV, Apollo only accepts the highest row in the file to update the record in the platform.

Most uploads only take a few minutes to complete, but depending on the size of your CSV and the time of day, it may take a few hours for your upload to finish. Apollo does not recommend uploading a file that includes more than 10k rows. Instead, you should split your CSV into two smaller files. title: Link Custom Salesforce Fields to Custom Apollo Fields
body: Overview While Salesforce provides many out-of-the-box fields that you can use to sync your data back and forth between Apollo, there may be data that is important to your business that you can't track with traditional metrics. For this reason, Salesforce and Apollo allow you to create custom fields to store that data. In order to leverage bi-directional sync between Apollo and Salesforce, you must first create a custom field in Salesforce and then link that field to a custom field in Apollo. Custom Fields

title: Create Global Picklists
body:
Overview Apollo allows you to create Custom Fields for contacts, accounts, opportunities, and users. Within a custom field, you have the option to choose the field Type. One of the more commonly used field Types is a Picklist. Custom Fields Type Types Picklist Picklists are defined lists of values (options) that you can use within custom contact, account, and user fields. They come in two varieties: Picklists Picklist: Allows you to select one option from a pre-defined list
Picklist (Multi-Select): Allows

title: Create Global Picklists
body: you to select one or more options from a pre-defined list The Apollo Global Picklist feature provides a way for you to leverage the same list of values for different custom Picklist fields. For example, say you have three custom Picklist fields—one for contacts, one for accounts, and one for opportunities—and they are all named "Health". In this case, rather than manually entering the same options for each custom Picklist field, you can create a Global Picklist that you can use in all three (or more).

title: Create Global Picklists
body: Global Picklist Picklist Picklist Picklist Global Picklist Refer to the section below for additional details about how to create global picklists within custom contact, account, and user fields.

title: Create Global Picklists
body: Create Global Picklists Log into Apollo and then click Settings. Settings Click Global Picklists. Global Picklists Click ++ New Global Picklist Value Set. + New Global Picklist Value Set In the new modal, type a Name for the Global Picklist Value Set. Name Global Picklist Value Set Click + Add Option to add a new Picklist Option to the Picklist. Repeat this process for as many options as you'd like to include. + Add Option Picklist Option Picklist If you need to remove an option, click the Delete  button

title: Create Global Picklists
body: next to it. Delete When you finish editing the Picklist, click Save. Picklist Save The Global Picklist is now available for you to use in any custom contact, account, or user field. Global Picklist For any existing Global Picklist, refer to the Currently Used By column on the Global Picklist page to determine which (if any) custom fields currently use it. Global Picklist Currently Used By Global Picklist

title: Add Contacts to a Sequence

Overview In Apollo, you can add contacts to a sequence in a few different ways. You can use the Apollo Search tool, upload a CSV file, or select contacts from a list. Refer to the sections below for detailed instructions about each method. One Trip Per Contact!
Please note, each included contact only gets one trip through each sequence step. Apollo tracks progress for contacts to avoid sending duplicate messaging. If you need a contact to go through the same series of sequence steps, clone the original

title: Prospect in LinkedIn
body: Overview Apollo allows you to search for and request details about prospects from LinkedIn Sales Navigator, LinkedIn, or directly from the Apollo database. View detailed information about a chosen company or contact, build detailed lists for use in Apollo sequences, view insights about a company, or view a contact's colleagues. These details help you find the right potential customers to engage and grow your business.

title: Prospect in LinkedIn
headings: Read the Doc > Find an Individual Prospect

Account Website (Domain) With these columns, Apollo can enrich the rest of the information about the lead and their account. Special CSV Column Circumstances

title: Upload a CSV of Accounts to Apollo
body:
will the upload take?
Most uploads only take a few minutes to complete, but depending on the size of your CSV and the time of day, it may take a few hours for your upload to finish. title: Access the Salesforce Error Log in Apollo
body: Overview The Error Log in Apollo allows you to view any sync errors that Apollo receives when pushing information from Apollo into Salesforce. From this page, you can browse through your error history, access further information about the error, filter by date and timeframe, and retry a failed sync. Error Log Refer to the sections below for the steps to take to access the Error Log, retry a "push" job, and gain a more granular view of a specific record's sync history. Error Log

title: Access the Salesforce Error Log in Apollo
headings: Overview > View Sync Errors and Retry the Push
body: View Sync Errors and Retry the Push Launch Apollo to view any sync errors that Apollo receives from your Salesforce instance, click Settings, and then click Integrations. Settings Integrations Click View in the connected Salesforce integration. View Then, scroll to Error Log and click View. Error Log View From this page, you can view any errors that occur when Apollo attempts to push information from Apollo into Salesforce. Click the Errors drop-down on the right to filter by push type. Errors You can also

title: Access the Salesforce Error Log in Apollo
headings: Overview > View Sync Errors and Retry the Push
body:
click the Dates drop-down to filter by date or timeframe. Dates To find out what caused an error, check the Error Description column. Error Description Check the Automatic Retry column to view if and when Apollo will automatically retry a failed push. Automatic Retry Hover your mouse over the information to view the date and time that Apollo plans to retry the push. Fifth Time's a Charm!
Please note, Apollo automatically attempts to retry a failed push 5 times. If this still does not work, you will need to

title: Access the Salesforce Error Log in Apollo
headings: Overview > View Sync Errors and Retry the Push
body:
address the error source and then manually retry the push. Fifth Time's a Charm!
Please note, Apollo automatically attempts to retry a failed push 5 times. If this still does not work, you will need to address the error source and then manually retry the push. Fifth Time's a Charm! Please note, Apollo automatically attempts to retry a failed push 5 times. If this still does not work, you will need to address the error source and then manually retry the push. If you want to manually retry a failed push,

title: Access the Salesforce Error Log in Apollo
headings: Overview > View Sync Errors and Retry the Push
body: click the checkbox(es) of the error(s), and then click Retry Selected. Retry Selected You have now requested for Apollo to re-attempt the push. If the push fails again, Apollo displays this on the Error Log.

title: Access the Salesforce Error Log in Apollo

CRM Sync History Apollo displays a modal with the sync history for the specific contact or account. From here, you can view information about both push and pull-related errors. contact account You have now accessed the error sync history for the contact or account.

Description


Settings Filters
Filters related to the most common fields (for example, lists, territories, custom fields, contact stage, etc.)


Person Info
Filters related to the individual contacts that you want to target (for example, name, title, location, job change, etc.)


Company Info
Filters related to the specific accounts that you want to target (for

Created Source

Miscellaneous

title: Sequences Overview
body: Overview Sequences are outreach campaigns with any number of sequential contact points and tasks that you can customize to personally engage your target audiences at scale. They help your team deliver communications to your customers and complete the right tasks at the right time to speed your prospects through your pipeline and turn them into paying customers as efficiently as possible. Sequences The benefits of Apollo sequences include: sequences Institutionalized best practices for engaging leads into

title: Sequences Overview
body:
easy-to-follow guides that automatically add defined tasks to your Apollo dashboards on set schedules, which ensures consistency and accountability for your sales team.
A/B testing for message templates, scripts, and strategies to confirm the best version of any step in your sales process.
Reporting to compare and optimize your approach and help you to confirm the best times for every message you send.
Reports include specific data relative to your messaging, such as how many messages were delivered,

title: Sequences Overview
body: opened, replied to, and bounced. As you use Apollo to hone in on your ideal customer profiles, create sequences to match each type of outbound and/or inbound prospect with automatic and manual messages, LinkedIn engagement, calls, and action items that speak directly to the value propositions they want. sequences

title: Sequences Overview
body:
Available Steps in a Sequence Sequence steps are the individual messages and activities you design for your team to successfully engage with prospects. Sequences are made up of as many steps and with as much time between each step as you choose. There are 8 types of steps to choose from: Sequence Sequences Automatic Email: Use any of your Apollo email templates or create new ones to craft personalized and targeted messaging that is delivered based on the parameters you set.

Manual Email: Use to schedule

title: Sequences Overview
body:
and deliver follow-up emails that you can fully customize for individual prospects.

Phone Call: Add notes, tips, scripts, and any other helpful information with a reminder to call a prospect.

Action Item: A blank canvas to schedule any number of necessary internal communications or processes along the way. Action items include a timeframe, priority, and notes for your team.

LinkedIn: View Profile: Access a contact's LinkedIn profile from within Apollo and document key information that can help you build

title: Sequences Overview
body:
rapport when engaging with prospects.

LinkedIn: Interact With Post: Review a contact's activities, engage with their recent posts, and give yourself direction with reminders and relevant notes.

LinkedIn: Send a Connection Request: Create connection request templates to make a great first impression.

LinkedIn: Send Message: Send personalized InMail messages using templates and snippets to personalize your approach at scale. Automatic Email Manual Email Phone Call Action Item LinkedIn: View Profile

title: Sequences Overview
body: LinkedIn: Interact With Post LinkedIn: Send a Connection Request LinkedIn: Send Message

title: Sequences Overview
body:
Timing or Spacing Between Steps There are 2 factors to determine how much time elapses between sequence steps: sequence Schedule: The sequence schedule sets the time and the day in which Apollo sends messages to prospects.

"Wait For" time in each step: The "Wait For" time in each step tells Apollo how long to wait in between each step in a sequence. Schedule sequence schedule "Wait For" time in each step sequence Find the Sweet Spot!

Sequence Rulesets Sequence rulesets allow you to edit default and advanced triggers that automatically update the stage of the contacts and/or the accounts they belong to whenever certain conditions are met as they go through a sequence. title: Reset Your Apollo Password
body: To reset your Apollo password, navigate to the Apollo website using the URL below: www.apollo.io www.apollo.io From the Apollo homepage (https://www.apollo.io/), click Login. https://www.apollo.io/ Login Click the Login tab. Then, scroll down to Forgot Your Password? and click the words Reset It Here. Login Forgot Your Password? Reset It Here Enter the email address connected to your Apollo account into both fields. Then, click Send Instructions. Send Instructions Apollo support will send a password reset

title: Reset Your Apollo Password
body:
link to your email account. A Watched Pot Never Boils!
Please note, it can take several minutes for your email to arrive so put up your feet, fire up a game of solitaire, or smash the patriarchy while you wait. title: Complete a LinkedIn Task in a Sequence
headings: Use a Sequence to Track Your LinkedIn Goals
body: Use a Sequence to Track Your LinkedIn Goals When you combine prospecting with LinkedIn and the ability to track tasks with sequences, you can reach your goals easier. You can create a sequence that tracks each step of your LinkedIn prospecting process. Launch Apollo and click Engage. sequences sequence Engage Click the sequence to which you want to add a LinkedIn step. sequence Click + Add Step. + Add Step Click the drop-down and choose the LinkedIn step you want to add. There are 4 different LinkedIn steps

title: Complete a LinkedIn Task in a Sequence
headings: Use a Sequence to Track Your LinkedIn Goals
body:
you can use in your sequence: sequence View Profile: This is a reminder for a member of your team to view a contact's LinkedIn profile to gain specific information such as education history, job history, current company details, and colleagues.

Interact with Post: This is a reminder for a member of your team to begin interacting with a contact's posts on LinkedIn. This could be as simpple as reacting to posts or something more in-depth like commenting.

Send a Connection Request: This is a reminder for a

title: Complete a LinkedIn Task in a Sequence
headings: Use a Sequence to Track Your LinkedIn Goals
body:
member of your team to send a connection request to a contact. Connections requests allow you to direct message a contact and, in some cases, is necessary to see and interact with the contact's posts.

Send Message: Send a direct message to a contact. This should be the last step to fostering a relationship with a contact through LinkedIn. You only want to message a contact if you are sure they would like to speak with you. Otherwise, it will feel like SPAM. View Profile contact's Interact with Post

Then, refer to the steps below to start enriching your records directly within Salesforce. Install the Apollo for Salesforce App

title: Use the Apollo for Salesforce App
body:
Enrich Records within Salesforce Launch Salesforce and navigate to the record page of any lead, contact, or account. Then, click the Apollo.io tab. lead contact account Apollo.io Apollo automatically enriches your Salesforce data when you click the Apollo.io tab. Apollo.io To review the enriched records, click the + icon next to a category in the Apollo.io tab. Then, scroll through your newly enriched data. + Apollo.io Playing It Safe
Please note, Apollo can only enrich the Salesforce accounts that include

title: Use the Apollo for Salesforce App
body:
a website in the record details. For Salesforce contacts and leads, Apollo can only enrich those that include either an email or the full combination of first name, last name, and company in the record details. Without these identifiers, Apollo cannot reliably match the records in the Apollo database and enrich the contact, lead, or account with confidence. Rest assured that if it’s not reliable, we ain’t wasting your credits! Playing It Safe

enrich a record without one of the identifiers mentioned above, Salesforce displays an error message. To overcome the error and enrich the record, click Details on the record page of the lead, contact, or account. Then, click the Edit icon next to the missing field(s). Details lead contact account Edit Enter the information and click Save. Save Then, click the Apollo tab and click Enrich. Enrich One Small Step for Security!
Please note, if your enrichment request failed the first time or if you have already

title: Use the Apollo for Salesforce App
body:
enriched a record within the last 30 days, you need to manually click the Enrich button after you click the Apollo.io tab to submit the request again. Apollo does not allow you to enrich a contact or lead more than once within a 30-day period. Every credit counts, after all! However, account enrichment does not cost you any credits. title: Set Task Priority
body: Overview Task priority helps you (or members of your team) to better plan your day and stay focused on the tasks that are most important first. You can mark steps in a sequence with a priority to provide ease of sorting in your daily task lists. Daily task lists, which are found on the "Home" screen and on a sequences and "Tasks" tab, are organized by calls, manual emails, and action items. You can sort task lists based on priority in either descending or ascending order. Refer to the sections below to

title: Set Task Priority
body: better understand how and where you can change or assign a priority for a task.

title: Set Task Priority
headings: Set Priority for Tasks in Sequences
body:
Set Priority for Tasks in Sequences Launch Apollo and then click Engage. Engage Open an existing sequence or click + New Sequence to build out a new one with tasks. + New Sequence Within your built-out sequence, click the additional options button next to any step and then click Edit. Edit Within the "Edit Step" modal click the Priority modal and then click the priority that you would like to apply to the step. Priority No Priority Settings for Automatic Emails
Please note, "Automatic Email" tasks do not

title: Set Task Priority
headings: Set Priority for Tasks in Sequences
body:
have a Priority dropdown since they do not require any interaction from an Apollo user before they send. No Priority Settings for Automatic Emails
Please note, "Automatic Email" tasks do not have a Priority dropdown since they do not require any interaction from an Apollo user before they send. No Priority Settings for Automatic Emails Please note, "Automatic Email" tasks do not have a Priority dropdown since they do not require any interaction from an Apollo user before they send. Priority When you're

title: Set Task Priority
headings: Set Priority for Tasks in Sequences
body: finished, click Save. Save Repeat this process for any additional tasks.

title: Set Task Priority
headings: Sort Tasks Priority on the Tasks Tab
body: Sort Tasks Priority on the Tasks Tab Launch Apollo and click Cockpit on the "Home" page. Cockpit From the "Cockpit" tab, click Complete My Daily Tasks. Complete My Daily Tasks Click the Sort by drop-down. Sort by Click the first drop-down in the new modal and then click Priority. Priority Click the second drop-down and select Ascending or Descending. Ascending Descending Click Apply. Apply Your task list is now sorted by priority.

title: Email Status Overview
body: Miscellaneous Filters Refer to the sections below for further details about each email status filter.

title: Email Status Overview
body:
Email Status Email Status
Description
Additional Information
Credits


Verified
A fully confirmed, valid email address. When you request a verified email, Apollo saves the data to your account.
At Apollo, verified emails maintain an email match rate of 84% and an accuracy rate of more than 90%. For more information, please read Email Verification: The Apollo Process.
Verified emails cost 1 credit per contact. 


Guessed
An email you have requested that Apollo is unable to fully verify.
If Apollo finds

title: Email Status Overview
body:
multiple pieces of evidence that suggest a probable email, Apollo marks it as guessed and indicates the confidence level. Apollo only returns guessed emails if the confidence level is 50% and above. Please note that guessed emails are more likely to bounce. Apollo recommends you use guessed emails in moderation to protect your domain reputation. For more information about best practices, please refer to the Avoid SPAM Filters article.
Apollo does not charge data credits for guessed emails.


User Managed
An

title: Email Status Overview
body:
email that you or your team have manually edited, imported via a CSV file, uploaded from your CRM, or created via the Apollo API.
This status filter only applies to the primary email of your saved contacts. Please note that the emails you edit or upload do not count as Apollo-verified emails. If you want Apollo to verify a user-managed email that you have amended or imported, you can choose to enrich the email. For more information about Apollo enrichment, please refer to the Enrich section of the Apollo

title: Email Status Overview
body:
KB.
You can upload new contacts or edit saved emails at no cost. If you want to verify an email you have amended, Apollo charges you 1 credit per contact.


New Data Available
A business email for which Apollo has updates. Apollo identifies when a contact changes jobs and displays the New Data Available status.
This status filter only applies to your saved contacts. For more information about job change alerts, refer to the Use Job Change Alerts to Update Contacts article.
Apollo charges 1 credit for every

title: Email Status Overview
body:
contact update you request.


N/A
An email that Apollo is unable to find or verify. If Apollo finds an email with a confidence score of 50% or less, Apollo marks it as N/A.

If you import contacts without email addresses via CRM integration or CSV file, Apollo assigns the contact the N/A status. You can then choose to enrich your contact data with the Apollo Enrichment tool.
For more information about Apollo Enrichment, refer to the Enrich section of the Knowledge Base.

Apollo does not charge you any email

credits for contacts without known, valid email addresses. Email Status

Got your eyes set on particular contacts or personas, but not all their emails display the "verified" status? It may be time to raise the stakes! Spread your wings and fly into the realms of guessed emails without taking too high of a risk. You can filter by level of confidence so the chance of bounce stays low. For example, you can choose to only send a message to

guessed emails with a confidence level of 90% and above. However, use this secret weapon in moderation to avoid high bounce rates and keep your domain healthy.

title: Miscellaneous Filters
body:
Overview Filters allow you to include or exclude specific subsets of data when you search for new Contacts or Accounts in Apollo. This helps you to better segment and personalize your team's approach so that you can find and engage with the right contacts at the right time. Filters Contacts Accounts You can access many types of Filters in Apollo. Filters Filter Types
Apollo divides all Filters into 6 main categories: Settings Filters, Person Info, Company Info, Engagement Activity, and Miscellaneous. Filter

title: Use Basic Dynamic Variables
body: Overview Dynamic variables allow you to personalize emails for individual contacts by leveraging data from the Apollo database, and in the case of custom dynamic variables, your own data research. You can leverage them in many parts of an email template including the subject line and the body copy. Dynamic variables dynamic variables Refer to the sections below about how to leverage basic dynamic variables in Apollo. dynamic variables

title: Use Basic Dynamic Variables
headings: Add Basic Dynamic Variables To An Email Template
body: Add Basic Dynamic Variables To An Email Template You can add basic dynamic variables to any existing template or any new template that you create. For additional information about creating email templates, please refer to the "Create and Edit Email Templates" article. dynamic variables Create and Edit Email Templates Within an email template, click the Add Dynamic Variables icon. Add Dynamic Variables The dynamic variables modal has tabs for three different snippet types: dynamic variables

title: Use Basic Dynamic Variables
headings: Add Basic Dynamic Variables To An Email Template
body:
Basic
Custom
Advanced Click a dynamic variable from the Basics tab. dynamic variable Basics The dynamic variable is added to the body of your email. dynamic variable If you would like to include the dynamic variable in the subject line, cut and paste it directly into the Subject text-box. dynamic variable Subject

title: Use Basic Dynamic Variables
headings: Available Dynamic Variables On the Basics Tab
body: Available Dynamic Variables On the Basics Tab The Basics tab provides a list of dynamic variables that leverage information about the individual contacts, time of day, or the company that a contact works for. Basics dynamic variables It is organized into three categories:

title: Use Advanced Dynamic Variables
body: Overview Advanced dynamic variables are somewhat different from basic dynamic variables in that they allow for limited conditional logic. Advanced dynamic variables basic dynamic variables basic dynamic variables That means advanced dynamic variables can provide a fallback in the event that there is no data for a specific field for a contact. This allows you to avoid having emails shipped to the Not Sent folder when you try to reach a contact with a dynamic variable for which Apollo has no data. advanced

title: Use Advanced Dynamic Variables
body: dynamic variables Not Sent Refer to the sections below for how to use all of the different types of advanced dynamic variables supported in Apollo email templates. advanced dynamic variables

title: Use Advanced Dynamic Variables
body:
Types of Advanced Dynamic Variables Advanced dynamic variables come in several different flavors: Advanced dynamic variables Empty Fallback
Dynamic Fallback
Letter Case and Pluralization Operators
Now-date/time Operators
Custom Date Operators Empty Fallback Dynamic Fallback Letter Case and Pluralization Operators Now-date/time Operators Custom Date Operators Each of these advanced dynamic variable types allows you to further personalize email templates for your customers. advanced dynamic variable

title: Use Advanced Dynamic Variables
headings: Types of Advanced Dynamic Variables > Advanced Dynamic Variables With an Empty Fallback
body: Advanced Dynamic Variables With an Empty Fallback The first type of advanced dynamic variable allows you to send templated emails to recipients without the fear of having them end up in the Not Sent folder when a basic dynamic variable does not render because of a lack of available data. In short, advanced dynamic variables with an empty fallback do not print any personalized text if it is not available in the Apollo database. advanced dynamic variable Not Sent basic dynamic variable advanced dynamic

title: Use Advanced Dynamic Variables
headings: Types of Advanced Dynamic Variables > Advanced Dynamic Variables With an Empty Fallback
body: variables Imagine that you want to send an email that greets each recipient by their first name. To accomplish that, you might decide to use the {{first_name}} dynamic variable to say something like: {{first_name}} Greetings {{first_name}}, If one of the contacts in your sequence does not have a first name in the Apollo database, the dynamic variable fails and Apollo moves your email to the Not Sent folder. Not Sent To avoid this, you could use the advanced dynamic variable {{#if first_name}}{{#endif}} to

title: Use Advanced Dynamic Variables
headings: Types of Advanced Dynamic Variables > Advanced Dynamic Variables With an Empty Fallback
body: create a generic fallback: advanced dynamic variable {{#if first_name}}{{#endif}} "Greetings {{#if first_name}}{{#endif}}, For recipients with first name data in the Apollo database, the dynamic variable renders in the email like this: Greetings John, Recipients without first name data in the Apollo database receive an email that renders like this: Greetings ,

title: Use Advanced Dynamic Variables
headings: Types of Advanced Dynamic Variables > Advanced Dynamic Variables With a Dynamic Fallback
body: Advanced Dynamic Variables With a Dynamic Fallback Advanced dynamic variables with a dynamic fallback go one step further than the empty fallback variety. These dynamic variables print text that you define in the event that there is no data for a particular field when a recipient opens a sequence email. Advanced dynamic variables Continuing with the scenario above, imagine that you want to use generic text in place of a recipient's first name if it is not available. If we use the following dynamic variable:

title: Use Advanced Dynamic Variables
headings: Types of Advanced Dynamic Variables > Advanced Dynamic Variables With a Dynamic Fallback
body: Hi {{#if first_name}}{{first_name}}{{#else}}there{{#endif}}, The email renders like the example below if no first name data is available on open: Hi there, If the recipient does have first name data available, the email will still render like this: Hi John, It's important to understand what each part of the dynamic variable does. The first part, {{#if first_name}}{{first_name}}, is the start of the conditional logic. It tells Apollo, "If there is a value for first name, render that first_name value in the

title: Use Advanced Dynamic Variables
headings: Types of Advanced Dynamic Variables > Advanced Dynamic Variables With a Dynamic Fallback
body: opened email." This is similar to what the basic dynamic variable {{first_name}} does with the exception of the inclusion of an {{#if}} statement. {{#if first_name}}{{first_name}} basic dynamic variable {{first_name}} {{#if}} The next part,{{#else}}there tells Apollo "If no first name value is available for this contact, use the text there instead." {{#else}}there there The final part, {{#endif}} tells Apollo that this is the end of the conditional logic for this dynamic variable. {{#endif}}

title: Use Advanced Dynamic Variables
headings: Types of Advanced Dynamic Variables > Advanced Dynamic Variables With Letter Case and Pluralization Operators > Advanced Dynamic Variables With Now-Date/Time Operators > Example Use Case For Advanced Dynamic Variables > Now-Time Dynamic Variables
body: Now-Time Dynamic Variables Continuing through the body copy, the dynamic variable {{now_year->plus_1}} tells Apollo to take the current year 2021 and add one year to it. When the recipient opens this email, this text renders as 2022. {{now_year->plus_1}} 2021 2022 Next, the dynamic variable {{now_weekday->plus_2}} tells Apollo to take the current day of the week and advance it by two days. If Apollo sends the email on a Monday, the text in the email renders as Wednesday. If Apollo sends the email on a

title: Use Advanced Dynamic Variables
headings: Types of Advanced Dynamic Variables > Advanced Dynamic Variables With Letter Case and Pluralization Operators > Advanced Dynamic Variables With Now-Date/Time Operators > Example Use Case For Advanced Dynamic Variables > Now-Time Dynamic Variables
body: Tuesday, the text renders as Thursday and so forth. If Apollo sends this email on a Thursday or Friday, the text will render the dynamic variable as Monday because it is the next available weekday. {{now_weekday->plus_2}} Wednesday Thursday Monday Subsequently, the {{now_weekday->plus_3}} dynamic variable tells Apollo to take the current day of the week and advance by three days. If Apollo sends the email on a Tuesday, the text in the email will render as Friday. If Apollo sends the email on a Wednesday,

title: Use Advanced Dynamic Variables
headings: Types of Advanced Dynamic Variables > Advanced Dynamic Variables With Letter Case and Pluralization Operators > Advanced Dynamic Variables With Now-Date/Time Operators > Example Use Case For Advanced Dynamic Variables > Now-Time Dynamic Variables
body: the text renders as Monday. Apollo renders the dynamic variable as the next available work day if the day of the week specified by the dynamic variable falls on a weekend day. {{now_weekday->plus_3}} Friday Monday Finally, the {{now_time_of_day}} dynamic variable tells Apollo to display the time of day for the recipient based on their local time in their local timezone (when it is available) and renders morning, afternoon, or evening. {{now_time_of_day}} morning afternoon evening

This allows you to send personalized emails with the help of automation. Refer to the section below for instructions on how to use a custom dynamic variable in an email template.

title: Use Custom Dynamic Variables
headings: Use A Custom Dynamic Variable in an Email Template
body: Use A Custom Dynamic Variable in an Email Template Launch Apollo and click Engage. Engage Create a new sequence or click one of your existing sequences to edit it. Click one of the "New Threads" in any manual or automatic email step. Place your cursor in the Body section of the "Edit Template" modal where you would like to add a Custom dynamic variable and then click Insert snippet. Body Custom dynamic variable Insert snippet Click the Custom fields tab. Custom fields Click a Custom dynamic variable from

title: Use Custom Dynamic Variables

body: the list to add it to your email template. Custom dynamic variable The dynamic variable renders in the "Preview" window if data is available for it. If you would like to use the dynamic variable in the subject line for your email template, cut and paste it into the Subject text-box. Subject Click Save Changes when you finish. Save Changes

title: Use Custom Dynamic Variables

body: Test Custom Dynamic Variables in an Email Template To generate a dynamic variable for a custom field, it needs to be updated for a specific contact or account profile. For this reason, you may want to test what will be displayed for a custom dynamic variable from an email template. Navigate to any thread in any manual or automatic email task within an Apollo sequence. To add a Custom dynamic variable to the body of your email, click Insert dynamic variable. title: Use Apollo Supported SIC Codes in a Search
body: Overview Standard Industrial Classification (SIC) codes are four-digit numerical codes assigned by the U.S. government to business establishments to identify the primary business of the establishment. The classification was developed to facilitate the collection, presentation and analysis of data; and to promote uniformity and comparability in the presentation of statistical data collected by various agencies of the federal government, state agencies, and private organizations. The classification covers all

title: Create and Edit Email Templates
headings: Create a New Template From the Navbar
body: Create a New Template From the Navbar Launch Apollo, hover your mouse over Engage in the navbar, and then click Templates. Engage Templates Click + New Template to create a new email template. + New Template In the new modal, give your template a name and add descriptive tags so you can find it later. The subject line supports the use of dynamic variables. Cut and paste the dynamic variable directly into the Subject text box to add a subject to your email template. Subject Next, create the body of your

title: Create and Edit Email Templates

For additional information, please refer to the "Use Basic Dynamic Variables", "Use Advanced Dyanmic Variables", and "Use Custom Dynamic Variables" articles. New Give the new sequence a name and then click + Create. + Create Click + Add Step to add a new step to the sequence. + Add Step In the "Wait for" text box, set the amount of time that Apollo should wait before sending out the email included in this step after you have activated the sequence.

title: Prevent Replies From Ending a Sequence
body: Overview Sequences are outreach campaigns with any number of sequential contact points and tasks that are customized to personally engage your target audiences at scale. They help your team deliver communications to your customers and complete the right tasks at the right time to speed your prospects through your pipeline and turn them into paying customers as efficiently as possible. By default, sequences end when a contact replies to an email, but there may be situations where you want the contact to

title: Prevent Replies From Ending a Sequence
body: continue through the sequence. Refer to the steps below to learn how to change the default setting for sequences.

title: Prevent Replies From Ending a Sequence
body: Change the Default Setting Launch Apollo, hover your mouse over Engage in the navbar, and then click Sequences. Engage Sequences Click the sequence for which you want to change the default setting. Click the More drop-down and then click Settings. More Settings Click Change under Sequence Ruleset:. Change Sequence Ruleset: Click the X to change the setting to No Ruleset. X No Ruleset Under Mark emails as Not Sent when the contact stage is any of:, click Replied to remove the condition. Mark emails as Not

title: Prevent Replies From Ending a Sequence
body: Sent when the contact stage is any of: Replied Click Show Default Triggers. Show Default Triggers Uncheck Mark contact as finished in sequence when there is a reply. Mark contact as finished in sequence when there is a reply Click Save Changes after you finish. Save Changes This sequence will no longer end for a contact by default when they reply to an email.

title: Sample Outbound Email Templates
body:
Overview When done correctly, outbound email is an effective way to engage with new prospects. It can help grow your business and expand your audience reach. Experimentation is important to a successful fully optimized outbound campaign. Be prepared to A/B test different messaging styles to find what works best for your target audiences. A/B test Refer to the templates below for examples of effective outbound emails. Modify the Templates to Fit Your Needs
Customization is key to ensuring your outbound

title: Sample Outbound Email Templates
body:
emails are a success. Remember to keep your target audience, your company voice, and your main goals at the front of your mind when you modify the templates below to meet the needs of a specific campaign. Modify the Templates to Fit Your Needs
Customization is key to ensuring your outbound emails are a success. Remember to keep your target audience, your company voice, and your main goals at the front of your mind when you modify the templates below to meet the needs of a specific campaign. Modify the

title: Sample Outbound Email Templates
body: Templates to Fit Your Needs Customization is key to ensuring your outbound emails are a success. Remember to keep your target audience, your company voice, and your main goals at the front of your mind when you modify the templates below to meet the needs of a specific campaign.

title: Sample Outbound Email Templates
body: Initial Contact Templates Each of these templates includes snippets to automatically pull in relevant information from a contact's profile. We have also included blanks to indicate where you should add additional personalization details. Keep in mind, while they are a good starting point, you may want to refine and customize them to best fit your goals and customer needs.

title: Sample Outbound Email Templates
body:
Sample 1: Subject: {{company}} <> [Your Company Name] Subject: Hi {{first_name}},

My name is _____ from _____.

We help {{industry}} companies with _______. I wanted to learn about how you handle ______ at {{company}} and show you what we're working on.

Are you available for a brief call on {{now_weekday->plus_1}} or {{now_weekday->plus_2}} this week?

title: Sample Outbound Email Templates
body:
Sample 2: Subject: {{company}} <> [Your Company Name] Subject: Hi {{first_name}},

I’m trying to figure out who is in charge of {{vertical}} at {{company}}.

Would you mind pointing me towards the right person and letting me know the best way to get in touch with them?

Thank you!

title: Sample Outbound Email Templates
body:
Sample 3: Subject: How to [insert value prop pitch] Subject: {{first_name}},

I’d like to discuss your _______. 

We’re helping other {{industry}} companies collect their prospects straight from professional social networks and import them directly into their CRMs (while enriching them with phone numbers and email addresses).

Quick question: can you put me in touch with whoever is responsible for {{vertical}} at {{company}}?

title: Sample Outbound Email Templates
body:
Sample 4: Subject: {{company}} + [Your Company Name] Subject: Hi {{first_name}}, 

My name is ___ and I’m a ___ at ___. We help {{title->plural}} ramp up their {{vertical}} efforts in minutes at companies like {{#if industry == industry marketing}}Sparks, Jumpshot, and Deepcrawl{{#else}} Segment, TalentBin, Sprig, and Poppin.{{#endif}} 

I wanted to learn about how you currently handle outbound sales and also show you what we’re working on.

Are you available for a quick call {{now_weekday->plus_1}} or

title: Sample Outbound Email Templates
body: {{now_weekday->plus_2}}?

title: Sample Outbound Email Templates
body:
Sample 5: Subject: Sales idea for {{company}} Subject: Hello {{first_name}},

What would it mean to your top-line revenue if you saw a 70% increase in contact rates, a 50% improvement in closes, and a 40% increase in quota-hitting sales reps?

Let’s find a few minutes to talk about how {{company}} provides these results to our clients.

I’m available in the {{now_time_of_day}} on {{now_weekday->plus_1}} or {{now_weekday->plus_2}}. Can we sync up?

title: Sample Outbound Email Templates
body:
Sample 6: Subject: [Your company/product's core value proposition] Subject: Hi {{first_name}},

I hope this message finds you well.

I work for a company called _____ that specializes in {{vertical}} solutions. Considering your role at {{company}}, I thought we might be a good fit for your group.

At ______, we have garnered a lot of attention and I think it’s something that your organization might see immediate value in.

Can you help me get in contact with the right decision-maker?

title: Sample Outbound Email Templates
body: Follow-Up Templates

title: Sample Outbound Email Templates
headings: Initial Contact Templates > Follow-Up Templates > Sample 1:
body:
Sample 1: Subject: RE: _____ Subject: Hi {{first_name}},

I just wanted to circle back on my email below re: Getting you a comments widget for your site. 

Are you free for a quick call on {{now_weekday->plus_1}} or {{now_weekday->plus_2}}? 

Across our partners' websites, we’re seeing an average increase of 1 minute on site with the addition of our widget. re: Getting you a comments widget for your site.

title: Sample Outbound Email Templates
headings: Initial Contact Templates > Follow-Up Templates > Sample 2:
body:
Sample 2: Subject: RE: _____ Subject: Hi {{first_name}},

I didn’t hear back from you last week when I was looking for the appropriate person managing ______ at {{company}}.

That’s not a problem. If it makes sense to talk, please let me know what your schedule looks like this week. If not, who is the appropriate person to speak with?

title: Sample Outbound Email Templates
headings: Initial Contact Templates > Follow-Up Templates > Sample 3:
body:
Sample 3: Subject: RE: _____ Subject: {{first_name}},

I’m hoping you can help me. 

Who handles the [insert pain point here] decisions at {{company}} and how might I get in touch with them? [insert pain point here]

title: Sample Outbound Email Templates
headings: Initial Contact Templates > Follow-Up Templates > Sample 4:
body:
Sample 4: Subject: [Competitor X and Competitor Y] Subject: Hi {{first_name}},

Just wanted to send you an example of how we’re working with {{#if industry == industry sales}}Competitor Name, and Competitor Name {{#else}} Competitor Name and Competitor Name{{#endif}} to deliver _____. 

Check it out here [link to example].

So far, feedback has been extremely positive. Would love to get you up and running—do you have a few minutes to chat this week? Competitor Name, and Competitor Name [link to example]

title: Sample Outbound Email Templates
headings: Initial Contact Templates > Follow-Up Templates > Sample 5:
body:
Sample 5: Subject: How we can help {{company}} Subject: {{first_name}},

We have a service that will help you [insert quick one-liner about the value your service delivers]. We've helped similar businesses achieve ________.

What’s the best day/time this week or next for a quick 15-minute conversation? [insert quick one-liner about the value your service delivers].

title: Avoid SPAM Filters
body:
Overview Email Service Providers (ESPs) often have strict rules in place to protect their users from unwanted or undesirable email messages. These "SPAM Blockers" can result in your emails bouncing and never reaching your intended audience. The strategies below can help you improve the delivery rates for the emails you send through Apollo. Let's (Not) Bounce
Please note, the tips and guidelines listed below are only best practices. They are not guaranteed to eliminate all bounces or instances of SPAM

title: Avoid SPAM Filters
body:
blocked emails. SPAM filtering is user-specific—if someone marks an email as spam, their email service provider's spam filtering will update itself to catch similar emails in the future. Two people can receive the same email and encounter different filtering behavior. Let's (Not) Bounce

body: Connect Apollo to a SendGrid Account SendGrid is a mass emailing service that uses its own email servers. It also replaces the tracking URLs and directs them to SendGrid servers to resolve deliverability issues. If you connect your Apollo account to SendGrid, you do not need to configure a Tracking Subdomain because SendGrid manages your tracking links on their end. title: Avoid SPAM Filters
headings: Email Deliverability Best Practices > Domain Reputation > Email Content and Formatting
body:
Email Content and Formatting Remove Links from the Body of Your Email: SPAM filters look for links, especially in first-contact emails. Your signature is scanned for links as well. Make sure you've removed links from your signature as well as in the body of your emails.

Remove Images from the Body of Your Email: Images or attachments, especially in first-contact emails, can activate SPAM blockers and cause bounces. Remove these assets and stick to text. Save your images and attachments for Step 3 or later

title: Avoid SPAM Filters
headings: Email Deliverability Best Practices > Domain Reputation > Email Content and Formatting
body:
in sequences once you've sent a few other emails. As with links, even images in your signature can cause issues.

Don't Apply Special Formatting to Your Text: Simply put, SPAM blockers scan for formatted text. Avoid using different colors, fonts, bolding, italicization, and underlining.

Keep Your Paragraphs Concise: Lengthy content can activate SPAM blockers or even cause bounces. Keep your wording simple and to the point.

Avoid Words that Trigger SPAM Filters: SPAM filters have evolved considerably in

title: Avoid SPAM Filters
headings: Email Deliverability Best Practices > Domain Reputation > Email Content and Formatting
body:
the past few years, and as such, there isn't a shortlist of words to avoid. In general, try to communicate in a professional, personable way and avoid words and phrases that sound suspicious, urgent, or needy. This HubSpot article provides a comprehensive list of words or phrases that you should avoid. As a best practice, ask yourself if the email you intend to send is one you would want to receive yourself.

A/B Test Your Messaging: Always test out your messaging to find what results in the highest

title: Avoid SPAM Filters
headings: Email Deliverability Best Practices > Domain Reputation > Email Content and Formatting
body: engagement. You can A/B test in Apollo to try multiple versions of a similar message. If you find one version is blocked at a higher rate, you can look at the differences in your messaging to try to understand the cause. Remove Links from the Body of Your Email Remove Images from the Body of Your Email Don't Apply Special Formatting to Your Text Keep Your Paragraphs Concise Avoid Words that Trigger SPAM Filters HubSpot article A/B Test Your Messaging

title: Avoid SPAM Filters
headings: Email Deliverability Best Practices > Domain Reputation > Additional Considerations
body: Additional Considerations While the measures listed below are not required, following their guidance may help to limit bounces and SPAM blocking for the emails you send through Apollo. Include an Unsubscribe Link in Your Email Signature: Apollo allows you to use whatever text/phrase you'd prefer in an opt-out link and automatically adds the link with your signature on all of the emails you send through the platform. Research shows that recipients are far more likely to use an unsubscribe link instead of

title: Avoid SPAM Filters
headings: Email Deliverability Best Practices > Domain Reputation > Additional Considerations
body:
marking your emails as SPAM. Marking your emails as SPAM can affect your overall sending reputation and is, therefore, a much worse outcome.

Deactivate Click Tracking: Click tracking manipulates links in emails, which SPAM filters can sometimes detect. Disable this feature if you're having issues by deactivating it in each user's profile. For additional information, please see the "Click Tracking in Apollo" article.

title: Set Up Sender Policy Framework (SPF) Records to Authorize Your Emails
body: Overview A Sender Policy Framework (SPF) record authorizes your emails with a mail server and confirms that you're the one sending e-mail from your domain. It does this by listing a range of IP addresses that are authorized to send on your behalf. A receiving email domain will likely detect anything outside of that range as a spoofed email or SPAM. Sender Policy Framework (SPF) Refer to the steps below to verify and edit your domain's SPF records. SPF

title: Set Up Sender Policy Framework (SPF) Records to Authorize Your Emails
body: Check Your SPF Record Settings Usually, your domain's SPF records are set by your IT department or domain/mail administrator. You can also check these records yourself with a tool like MX Toolbox. SPF MX Toolbox Within MX Toolbox, enter your domain name in the SPF Record Lookup bar and click the button next to it. If your email address is tom@jerry.com, the domain name is jerry.com. SPF Record Lookup tom@jerry.com jerry.com This domain doesn't have an SPF record so the tool displays "No SPF Record found"

title: Set Up Sender Policy Framework (SPF) Records to Authorize Your Emails
body: under Result. SPF Result Conversely, if your domain does have an SPF record, it displays it under Result. SPF Result Your SPF record settings are now verified. Follow the steps below to fix the record (if necessary) or to confirm the settings with your IT department or domain/mail administrator. SPF

title: Set Up Sender Policy Framework (SPF) Records to Authorize Your Emails
headings: Add or Update Your SPF Record
body: Add or Update Your SPF Record If you followed the steps above and found an SPF record, there's no need to add or update it. If the tool did not find a record, your email's DNS provider provides the criteria to fix it. Popular providers include Google Workspace or Office 365. If you use these providers, you can refer to these links to confirm the settings and add or update your SPF records accordingly. Your domain administrator should be familiar with the process.​ SPF Google Workspace Office 365 SPF Google

title: Contact and Account Stages Overview
body: Overview Contact and account stages in Apollo help you track your progress on sales and marketing pipelines. They also label each account or contact with a progress designation. The additional analytical insights can help increase productivity as well. Refer to the sections below for examples and suggestions on how to set up contact and account stages.

title: Contact and Account Stages Overview
body: Stage Descriptions There are several default Contact Stages and Account Stages in Apollo: Contact Stages Account Stages

body:

Description


Cold
This is a new contact who you have not emailed, called, or reached out to before.


Approaching
You have sent the contact at least 1 message or have called them.


Replied
This contact has replied to your email.


Interested

title: Set Up Domain-based Message Authentication Reporting and Conformance (DMARC) to Authenticate Your Emails
labels: Domain-based Message Authentication Reporting and Conformance
body: Overview Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance (DMARC) is a standard email authentication method that helps you prevent hackers from spoofing your organization for malicious purposes and allows you to limit sent emails to those authenticated by your organization. DMARC's most basic function is to tell receiving email servers what to do with outgoing messages from your domain that don’t pass the Sender Policy Framework (SPF) or Domain Keys Identified Mail (DKIM) checks. Setting up

title: Set Up Domain-based Message Authentication Reporting and Conformance (DMARC) to Authenticate Your Emails
labels: Domain-based Message Authentication Reporting and Conformance
body: DMARC also allows you to generate reports to make sure your emails aren't being spoofed. Domain-based Message Authentication, Reporting & Conformance (DMARC) DMARC's Sender Policy Framework (SPF) Domain Keys Identified Mail (DKIM) DMARC Refer to the sections below to verify and configure your DMARC settings. DMARC

title: Set Up Domain-based Message Authentication Reporting and Conformance (DMARC) to Authenticate Your Emails
labels: Domain-based Message Authentication Reporting and Conformance
body: Verify DMARC Configuration Usually, your domain's DMARC policies are set by your IT rep or domain/mail administrator, but you can also check them yourself with a tool like MX Toolbox. DMARC MX Toolbox Within MX Toolbox, enter your domain name in the search bar and click DMARC Lookup. DMARC Lookup The Result column shows your current DMARC configuration. Result DMARC You have now verified your DMARC configuration. DMARC

title: Set Up Domain Keys Identified Mail (DKIM) to Authenticate Your Email
body: Overview Domain Keys Identified Mail (DKIM) is an authentication method that uses cryptography to add an encrypted digital signature to your organization's outgoing emails. In this method, your mail server uses a private key to encrypt the email data and receiving email servers retrieve the corresponding public key to decrypt it. This ensures that your email is genuinely sent from your domain and hasn’t been altered on its way to the recipient. It also raises your spam score, which increases the chances of

title: Set Up Domain Keys Identified Mail (DKIM) to Authenticate Your Email
body: your emails being delivered. Domain Keys Identified Mail (DKIM) Refer to the sections below to verify and configure your DKIM settings. DKIM

title: Set Up Domain Keys Identified Mail (DKIM) to Authenticate Your Email
body:
Verify Your DKIM Configuration Usually, your domain's DKIM configuration is set by your IT rep or domain/mail administrator, but you can also check yourself using a tool such as MX Toolbox. DKIM MX Toolbox In its most basic form, DKIM can be verified using two elements: DKIM Your organization's domain name (for example, apollo.io)
A DKIM selector is the text added with the domain to create a unique DNS record used during DKIM.

This allows different systems, date ranges, or third-party services to create

body: export all for a list of more than 50,000 saved records, Apollo creates multiple CSVs. contacts export all You have now exported all saved contacts from Apollo to a CSV. When the export is complete, Apollo notifies you via email. contacts You can also check the status of the export directly in Apollo. Click Settings and then click Import & Exports. Select the CSV Exports tab. Settings Import & Exports CSV Exports Click the export to download the CSV file.

title: Sequence Statistics Overview
body:
Overview Each sequence in Apollo has its own set of statistics. This data is divided into two categories: Contact Stage statistics
Email Tracking statistics Refer to the sections below for additional details about each type.

title: Sequence Statistics Overview
body:
Contact Stage Statistics "Contact Stage" statistics are available on the lefthand side of the sequence screen. Click for Additional Details
Please note, clicking on an individual statistic will bring you to the relevant stage in your sequence's Contacts tab. Click for Additional Details
Please note, clicking on an individual statistic will bring you to the relevant stage in your sequence's Contacts tab. Click for Additional Details Please note, clicking on an individual statistic will bring you to the

title: Sequence Statistics Overview
body:
relevant stage in your sequence's Contacts tab. Contacts "Contact Stage" statistics provide the following data points: Active: The total number of contacts who are currently in the sequence

Paused: The total number of contacts who are currently in the sequence, but are paused on a certain step

Finished: The total number of contacts who have either completed the sequence or met a Mark sequence as finished trigger in the sequence's Settings tab

Bounced: The total number of contacts who had their email

title: Sequence Statistics Overview
body:
bounce after receiving a message in the sequence

Not sent: The total number of contacts who have met a Mark as failed when trigger in the sequence's Settings tab Active Paused Finished Mark sequence as finished Settings Bounced Not sent Mark as failed when Settings

title: Sequence Statistics Overview
body:
Email Tracking Statistics Potential Data Mismatch
Please note, the totals in the Delivered and Open categories will rarely line up with the Overview tab and the Emails tab. This is because the Emails tab shows stats relative to the emails themselves, rather than the contacts who were emailed. The Overview tab shows stats relative to those contacts. It's possible to deliver more than one message to a contact in a sequence and this explains the discrepancy. Potential Data Mismatch

Emails "Email Tracking" statistics provide the following data points: Scheduled: The total number of contacts currently scheduled to receive a

title: Sequence Statistics Overview
body:
message in the sequence

Delivered: The total number of contacts who have been delivered at least one message in the sequence

Open: The total number of contacts who have opened at least one message in the sequence

Click: The total number of contacts who have clicked at least one link in the sequence's messages

Reply: The total number of contacts who have replied to at least one of the sequence's messages

Interested: The total number of contacts who were marked as interested after receiving one of the

title: Sequence Statistics Overview
body:
sequence's messages, or accepting a calendar invite

Opt out: The total number of contacts who have clicked an opt-out (unsubscribe) link in one of the sequence's messages Scheduled Delivered Open Click Reply Interested Opt out Aggregate statistics are determined by the total number of emails delivered in the sequence. The overall sequence percentages are calculated by dividing by the total number of emails delivered. When you hover your mouse over the percentages, you will then see the numerical count for

title: Sequence Statistics Overview
body:
that stat. In the example above, the 82.2% open rate for the sequence is determined by the total number of open emails (106) divided by the total number of delivered emails (129). Email stats in individual sequence steps are calculated the same way as the aggregate—dividing by the total number of emails delivered for that one message. Where is My Mind...er...Data?
Please note, if you delete contacts from your account, Apollo reflects this change in the statistics header under the "Emails" tab.
  
Apollo

title: Sequence Statistics Overview
body:
deletes the records of any emails that you sent to the deleted contacts; however, the “Overview” tab still displays statistics for every email that you have sent since you activated the sequence. Where is My Mind...er...Data?
Please note, if you delete contacts from your account, Apollo reflects this change in the statistics header under the "Emails" tab.
  
Apollo deletes the records of any emails that you sent to the deleted contacts; however, the “Overview” tab still displays statistics for every email

title: Sequence Statistics Overview
body: that you have sent since you activated the sequence. Where is My Mind...er...Data? Please note, if you delete contacts from your account, Apollo reflects this change in the statistics header under the "Emails" tab. Apollo deletes the records of any emails that you sent to the deleted contacts; however, the “Overview” tab still displays statistics for every email that you have sent since you activated the sequence.

title: Display People With Verified Emails
body:
Overview You may not want to potentially endanger your domain or send score, or worse, have your domain spam-blocked. For this reason, there may be instances where you need to show search results for people for which Apollo has a verified email. To do this, you can add an Email Status filter to your search. Please note, Score Rules are not related to the Apollo Rules Engine. Score Rules define your Scoring Model while the Rules Engine helps you automate actions in Apollo that would otherwise require manual input. Read the

title: Merge Account Data Overview
body:
Overview When you merge duplicate contact information in the platform, Apollo only merges certain information into the correct record. How to Merge Duplicate Records
For more information on how to merge duplicate records, click here. How to Merge Duplicate Records
For more information on how to merge duplicate records, click here. How to Merge Duplicate Records For more information on how to merge duplicate records, click here. click here Refer to the section below for information about rules Apollo applies

title: Merge Account Data Overview
body: when merging records in your account.

title: Merge Account Data Overview
body:
General Rules for Merging Generally speaking, when a duplicate entry merges with your source of truth, Apollo migrates the following fields into the source of truth: Account custom field values that aren't null
Account lists
Contacts
User activities The merge process in Apollo operates on priority. The source of truth entry takes precedent over the entry you merged in. For example, when Apollo merges custom fields, if the source of truth has a different value for the same custom field, it is not

title: Merge Account Data Overview
body:
overwritten. If the custom field is empty in the source of truth, Apollo merges the data into the source of truth. not Account lists, contacts, and user activities are added to the existing list in the source of truth. In addition, the following information is also copied over in a merge, if it is available: Account Name
Account Enrichment Information
Account Website
Account Notes
Account Stage
Account Owner

title: Integrate Apollo with Your Zoom Account
body: is currently in Beta. If you do not have access to Apollo Conversations just yet, we haven't forgotten you! Please bear with us while we fine-tune the magic formula. Apollo Conversations If your team uses Zoom for sales or recruitment calls, you can integrate your Apollo instance with your Zoom account to access your call recordings and leverage important meeting insights from within Apollo. There are several benefits of integrating Zoom with Apollo, including: More effectively manage and analyze your

title: Integrate Apollo with Your Zoom Account
body:
team’s call recordings
Play back your call recordings, download high-accuracy transcripts, and uncover account and attendee data from each call
Coach and scale successful conversations to increase call conversions
Stay fully compliant and leverage industry-leading video quality from Zoom with every recording that you view, manage, and analyze within Apollo. Refer to the steps below to set up the Zoom integration in Apollo, configure the settings, and if needed, disconnect the integration from both ends.

title: Open Tracking Overview
body:
Overview Email tracking systems, which inform you when your emails are opened, use a 1-pixel image called a tracking pixel to obtain interaction data. Each tracking pixel contains individualized code to attribute to the recipient and to the email which they receive. Additionally, if the recipient downloads the image, Apollo also logs it as an email open event. tracking pixel tracking pixel Pixel Tracking Image URL
Apollo's tracking pixel is hosted on Heroku, so that pixel displays as a Heroku URL. Pixel

title: Open Tracking Overview
body:
Tracking Image URL
Apollo's tracking pixel is hosted on Heroku, so that pixel displays as a Heroku URL. Pixel Tracking Image URL Apollo's tracking pixel is hosted on Heroku, so that pixel displays as a Heroku URL.

title: Open Tracking Overview
body:
Open Tracking Considerations Sometimes, email tracking systems mark an email as opened when they are not actually opened. The following scenarios cause false positives: false positives In Outlook, the recipient can view the email from the preview pane.

This causes the tracking pixel to download even though they didn't actually click on the email. 


The email recipient has a Google or G Suite address

As Google always proxies every link in an email, they may visit the link as a test. This can trigger an

title: Open Tracking Overview
body:
open event without the recipient ever reading the email. It is not a guaranteed outcome, but it is possible.


On mobile, the Gmail app displays the email on a preview screen.

This sometimes triggers an email open event without the user seeing more than just the subject and first few words. This causes the tracking pixel to download even though they didn't actually click on the email. As Google always proxies every link in an email, they may visit the link as a test. This can trigger an open event without

title: Open Tracking Overview
body: the recipient ever reading the email. It is not a guaranteed outcome, but it is possible. This sometimes triggers an email open event without the user seeing more than just the subject and first few words. On the other hand, false negatives are also possible. This occurs when a contact opened your email and the tracking pixel was not downloaded so it did not trigger an open event. If your contact has set their email to not download images automatically, you may get incomplete data. false negatives The

title: Open Tracking Overview
body: easiest way to combat this and improve your open data is to include a clickable link in your email. This ensures that anyone who clicked your link opened and reads your message.

title: Open Tracking Overview
headings: Enhance Open Rates with A/B Testing
body: Enhance Open Rates with A/B Testing A/B Testing helps to increase your open rates. By sending multiple versions of the same email, you can analyze the data to discover which version the recipients find most engaging. Use this data to tweak your messaging and enhance your open rates. A/B Testing Read Add an A/B Test to an Email Step in a Sequence for more information. Add an A/B Test to an Email Step in a Sequence

title: Open Tracking Overview
body: Low Open Rate Concerns More often than not, low open rates for your emails are the direct result of bad deliverability and issues with your domain's reputation. Some email providers may report emails as successfully delivered, but instead, move them to a contact's SPAM folder. That means a contact never actually viewed or opened the email. If a contact doesn't view your email, open rates remain low. To help avoid emails blocked by SPAM filters, please see the Avoid SPAM Filters article to review Apollo's

title: Open Tracking Overview
body: suggestions for improving your domain's reputation. Avoid SPAM Filters

title: Make and Receive VoIP Calls
body:
Overview You can make and receive Voice Over IP (VoIP) calls in Apollo. This allows you to use your computer instead of a phone for calls. Follow the sections below to learn how to make and receive VoIP calls. Dialer Availability
Please note, the dialer is available for customers in the Professional and Custom pricing plans. If you have a Professional plan, you may make and receive phone calls only within the United States. Apollo provides 10 minutes of dialing time per dollar spent on your Professional

title: Make and Receive VoIP Calls
body:
subscription. If you have a Custom plan, you may make calls within the United States and internationally (pending approval). Apollo provides 3 minutes of international dialing time per dollar spent on your Custom subscription.
Apollo counts your talk time by the second, not by the minute. If you talk for 32 seconds, Apollo does not round up to the closest minute—we count 32 seconds, just as it should be. Dialer Availability

If you are on a Professional or Custom plan, you have access to the Apollo Dialer. However, on a Professional plan, you can only make calls within the United States. title: Countries With Available International Phone Numbers
body:
Dialer Availability
Please note, international dialing and phone numbers are only available for customers who have purchased Custom plans. If you have a professional plan, you may make and receive phone calls only within the United States. Apollo provides 10 minutes of dialing time per dollar spent on your professional subscription. If you have a custom plan, you may make calls within the United States and internationally (pending approval). Apollo provides 3 minutes of international dialing time per dollar

title: Create Call Dispositions to Log Your Calls

Apollo defines "Connected" and "Not Connected" in specific ways. "Connected" means the call went through to the desired contact and will be marked as "Finished" in the sequence. "Not Connected" means you didn't reach the intended contact, even if the

title: Create Call Dispositions to Log Your Calls
body:
call went through to another person. The contact will continue to the next step in the sequence. (Dis)connect the Dots
Apollo defines "Connected" and "Not Connected" in specific ways. "Connected" means the call went through to the desired contact and will be marked as "Finished" in the sequence. "Not Connected" means you didn't reach the intended contact, even if the call went through to another person. The contact will continue to the next step in the sequence. title: Playbooks Overview (BETA)
body:
Overview Playbooks are engagement tools you can use to group accounts through an ordered series of steps that must be completed during the engagement process. You can think of Playbooks like Sequences, but for accounts instead of contacts. You can also have multiple Playbooks operating simultaneously. Playbooks accounts Playbooks Sequences accounts contacts Playbooks Playing With Playbooks vs. Stepping Through Sequences
